headline: In Return Home to Mexico Grave, an Industry Rises
print_headline: In Journey Home To Mexico Grave, An Industry Rises
abstract: For many Mexicans the sojourn to the United States, legal or not, is meant to be temporary.
snippet: For many Mexicans the sojourn to the United States, legal or not, is meant to be temporary.
lead_paragraph: CONWAY, Ark. — Héctor Acevedo was 22, in this country illegally and far from his mother when he died last month in a car accident outside of town just across the Arkansas River.

headline: Judges Say U.S. Can’t Hold Man as ‘Combatant’
print_headline: judges say u.s. can’t hold man as ‘combatant’
abstract: A federal appeals court ruled that the president may not declare civilians in this country to be “enemy combatants” and have the military hold them indefinitely.
snippet: A federal appeals court ruled that the president may not declare civilians in this country to be “enemy combatants” and have the military hold them indefinitely.
lead_paragraph: The federal appeals court in Richmond, Va., ruled yesterday that the president may not declare civilians in this country to be “enemy combatants” and have the military hold them indefinitely. The ruling was a stinging rejection of one of the Bush administration’s central assertions about the scope of executive authority to combat terrorism.

headline: Palestinian Split Deepens; Government in Chaos
print_headline: Palestinian Split Deepens, With Government in Chaos
abstract: With Hamas tightening its control of the Gaza Strip amid more bloodshed, the Palestinian territories seemed headed toward a turbulent political divide.
snippet: With Hamas tightening its control of the Gaza Strip amid more bloodshed, the Palestinian territories seemed headed toward a turbulent political divide.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM, June 14 — The Palestinian territories seemed headed Thursday to a turbulent political divide. Masked Hamas gunmen took control of the Gaza Strip and the Fatah president dissolved the 3-month-old unity government, declaring a state of emergency and plans for elections.

headline: Facing Sanction, Duke Prosecutor Plans to Resign
print_headline: facing sanction, duke prosecutor says he’ll resign
abstract: At a disciplinary hearing, Michael B. Nifong apologized to three lacrosse players and their families.
snippet: At a disciplinary hearing, Michael B. Nifong apologized to three lacrosse players and their families.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C., June 15 —Michael B. Nifong, the Durham County district attorney, announced Friday that he would resign, as he faces disciplinary charges for his handling of a sexual assault prosecution against three former Duke University lacrosse players who were later declared innocent.

headline: As More Toys Are Recalled, Trail Ends in China
print_headline: As More Toys Are Recalled, the Trail Ends in China
abstract: China manufactured every one of the 24 kinds of toys recalled for safety reasons in the United States this year.
snippet: China manufactured every one of the 24 kinds of toys recalled for safety reasons in the United States this year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 18 — China manufactured every one of the 24 kinds of toys recalled for safety reasons in the United States so far this year, including the enormously popular Thomas & Friends wooden train sets, a record that is causing alarm among consumer advocates, parents and regulators.

headline: Bloomberg Severs G.O.P. Ties, Fueling Further Talk of ’08 Bid
print_headline: Bloomberg Severs G.O.P. Ties, Fueling Further Talk of ’08 Bid
abstract: The step could clear the way for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York to make an independent bid for the presidency.
snippet: The step could clear the way for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York to make an independent bid for the presidency.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, June 19 — Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced Tuesday that he was dropping his Republican affiliation, a step that could clear the way for him to make an independent bid for the presidency.

headline: Militants Said to Flee Before U.S. Offensive
print_headline: TOP TARGETS FLED BEFORE U.S. PUSH, COMMANDER SAYS
abstract: The second-ranking U.S. commander in Iraq said that Qaeda leaders had been alerted to a plan for an American push in Baquba.
snippet: The second-ranking U.S. commander in Iraq said that Qaeda leaders had been alerted to a plan for an American push in Baquba.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, June 22 — The operational commander of troops battling to drive fighters with Al Qaeda from Baquba said Friday that 80 percent of the top Qaeda leaders in the city fled before the American-led offensive began earlier this week. He compared their flight with the escape of Qaeda leaders from Falluja ahead of an American offensive that recaptured that city in 2004.

headline: General’s Iraq Progress Report Has Competition
print_headline: General’s Report On Iraq Progress Has Competition
abstract: The Bush administration will seek a range of views beyond the report by the U.S. commander in Iraq.
snippet: The Bush administration will seek a range of views beyond the report by the U.S. commander in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 23 — Last month, Congress set a deadline for the American commander in Iraq, declaring that by Sept. 15 he would have to assess progress there before billions more dollars are approved to finance the military effort to stabilize the country. The commander, Gen. David H. Petraeus, said in recent days that his report would be only a snapshot of trends, strongly suggesting he will be asking for more time.

headline: Chef Sues Over Intellectual Property (the Menu)
print_headline: Chef Sues Over Intellectual Property (the Menu)
abstract: A lawsuit by the owner of Pearl Oyster Bar in Manhattan may be the most aggressive use of intellectual property concepts by the owner of a small restaurant.
snippet: A lawsuit by the owner of Pearl Oyster Bar in Manhattan may be the most aggressive use of intellectual property concepts by the owner of a small restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, Rebecca Charles wishes she were a little less influential.

headline: New Senators Resist Overhaul of Immigration
print_headline: New Senators Resist Overhaul Of Immigration
abstract: Three moderate Democratic freshmen are complicating efforts by President Bush and Senate leaders to pass a proposed immigration measure this week.
snippet: Three moderate Democratic freshmen are complicating efforts by President Bush and Senate leaders to pass a proposed immigration measure this week.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 27 — In narrowly winning her seat last year, Senator Claire McCaskill of Missouri ran hard against what she saw as a flawed approach in Congress to dealing with illegal immigration. Ms. McCaskill, a Democratic newcomer, says she is not about to change her view now.

headline: Life in a Cage: Baby Sleeps, Mom Cooks, Dad Bats
print_headline: Home in the Cage: Mom Cooks, The Baby Sleeps, and Dad Bats
abstract: For three years, Angels outfielder Reggie Willits has chosen to live with his family in an indoor batting cage.
snippet: For three years, Angels outfielder Reggie Willits has chosen to live with his family in an indoor batting cage.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif., June 26 — When Amber Willits is cooking dinner — crack! — or putting the baby to bed — crack! — or trying to get a little sleep herself — crack! — she has to wonder why she ever agreed to live in a batting cage.

headline: Labels Lack Food’s Origin Despite Law
print_headline: Labels Lack Food’s Origin Despite Law
abstract: Lobbyists and lawmakers have held off on enforcing a law requiring country-of-origin labels on meat and produce.
snippet: Lobbyists and lawmakers have held off on enforcing a law requiring country-of-origin labels on meat and produce.
lead_paragraph: In every American supermarket, labels tell shoppers where their seafood came from. But there are no such labels for meat, produce or nuts.

headline: Surge Seen in Applications for Citizenship
print_headline: Sharp Rise Seen In Applications For Citizenship
abstract: New feelings of insecurity in immigrant communities are helping fuel a rise in the number of legal immigrants seeking to become U.S. citizens.
snippet: New feelings of insecurity in immigrant communities are helping fuel a rise in the number of legal immigrants seeking to become U.S. citizens.
lead_paragraph: The number of legal immigrants seeking to become United States citizens is surging, officials say, prompted by imminent increases in fees to process naturalization applications, citizenship drives across the country and new feelings of insecurity among immigrants.

headline: London Bombers Sped to Glasgow, Authorities Say
print_headline: London bombers sped to Glasgow, Authorities Say
abstract: A week after the intended bombings, evidence is emerging that two doctors were the main operatives, if not leaders, of a network of other medical professionals.
snippet: A week after the intended bombings, evidence is emerging that two doctors were the main operatives, if not leaders, of a network of other medical professionals.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, Scotland, July 5 — British investigators have concluded that the two men who carried out an attack at Glasgow’s international airport last Saturday had sped there after a failed attempt to bomb a nightclub in central London, a British security official said Thursday.

headline: New York Plans Surveillance Veil for Downtown
print_headline: POLICE PLAN WEB OF SURVEILLANCE FOR DOWNTOWN
abstract: The program would include license plate readers and 3,000 security cameras below Canal Street.
snippet: The program would include license plate readers and 3,000 security cameras below Canal Street.
lead_paragraph: By the end of this year, police officials say, more than 100 cameras will have begun monitoring cars moving through Lower Manhattan, the beginning phase of a London-style surveillance system that would be the first in the United States.

headline: As War Enters Classrooms, Fear Grips Afghans
print_headline: As War Enters Classrooms, Fear Grips Afghans
abstract: The Taliban and other militant groups in Afghanistan are taking aim at hundreds of public schools.
snippet: The Taliban and other militant groups in Afghanistan are taking aim at hundreds of public schools.
lead_paragraph: QALAI SAYEDAN, Afghanistan, July 9 — With their teacher absent, 10 students were allowed to leave school early. These were the girls the gunmen saw first, 10 easy targets walking hand-in-hand through the blue metal gate and on to the winding dirt road.

headline: A Chinese Reformer Betrays His Cause, and Pays
print_headline: A Chinese Reformer Betrays His Cause, and Pays
abstract: The Chinese regulator who was executed Tuesday was corrupted by the system he sought to change.
snippet: The Chinese regulator who was executed Tuesday was corrupted by the system he sought to change.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING, July 12  — Zheng Xiaoyu once ranked as one of the most powerful regulators in China. He rose from modest beginnings to help create and lead Beijing’s version of the Food and Drug Administration in the United States.

headline: Market Forces Cited in Lymphoma Drugs’ Disuse
print_headline: 2 Lymphoma Drugs Go Unused, And Backers Cite Market Forces
abstract: Only about 10 percent of people who are suitable candidates for two drugs received one of them last year.
snippet: Only about 10 percent of people who are suitable candidates for two drugs received one of them last year.
lead_paragraph: The patients’ stories sound nearly impossible.

headline: Bush to Bolster Abbas and Seek Peace Talks
print_headline: Bush to Bolster Abbas and Push For Peace Talks

snippet: The Bush administration signaled that it will make a major push for peace between Israelis and Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 16 — President Bush announced an initiative on Monday to shore up the Palestinian president and to begin building a Palestinian state, signaling that his administration will use its remaining months to make a major push for peace between Israelis and Palestinians.

headline: Fingers Point as Traffic Plan Runs Aground
print_headline: Fingers Point As Traffic Plan Runs Aground

snippet: State officials say that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg used a doomed strategy to push for congestion pricing.
lead_paragraph: It was supposed to be different this time. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his aides conducted elaborate analyses and an intricate media campaign, not to mention all the detailed strategy sessions with advocates and experts, to develop and promote the mayor’s traffic congestion pricing plan.

headline: Google Pushes for Rules to Aid Wireless Plans
print_headline: Google Pushes For Rules to Aid Wireless Plans
abstract: The Internet giant, which may bid for a swath of U.S. airwaves, is lobbying to support a vision that could change how millions of Americans use cellphones.
snippet: The Internet giant, which may bid for a swath of U.S. airwaves, is lobbying to support a vision that could change how millions of Americans use cellphones.
lead_paragraph: If Google succeeds with federal regulators, it could change the way millions of Americans use their cellphones and how they connect to the Internet on their wireless devices.

headline: New Leaders Say Pensive French Think Too Much
print_headline: New Leaders Say Pensive French Think Too Much
abstract: In the country of the Enlightenment, President Nicolas Sarkozy’s government advocates hard work, not musing.
snippet: In the country of the Enlightenment, President Nicolas Sarkozy’s government advocates hard work, not musing.
lead_paragraph: PARIS, July 21 — France is the country that produced the Enlightenment, Descartes’s one-liner, “I think, therefore I am,” and the solemn pontifications of Jean-Paul Sartre and other celebrity philosophers.

headline: Top Lender Sees Mortgage Woes for ‘Good’ Risks
print_headline: TOP LENDER SEES MORTGAGE WOES FOR ‘GOOD’ RISKS
abstract: Countrywide Financial, the nation’s largest mortgage lender, said yesterday that more borrowers with good credit were falling behind on their loans.
snippet: Countrywide Financial, the nation’s largest mortgage lender, said yesterday that more borrowers with good credit were falling behind on their loans.
lead_paragraph: Countrywide Financial, the nation’s largest mortgage lender, said yesterday that more borrowers with good credit were falling behind on their loans and that the housing market might not begin recovering until 2009 because of a decline in house prices that goes beyond anything experienced in decades.

headline: Find Yourself Packing It On? Blame Friends
print_headline: Find Yourself Packing It On? Look Around at Your Friends
abstract: Obesity can spread from person to person, much like a virus, researchers report.
snippet: Obesity can spread from person to person, much like a virus, researchers report.
lead_paragraph: Obesity can spread from person to person, much like a virus, researchers are reporting today. When one person gains weight, close friends tend to gain weight, too.

headline: As U.S. Rebuilds, Iraq Won’t Act on Finished Work
print_headline: As U.S. Rebuilds, Iraqi Minister Won’t Take Over Finished Work
abstract: Iraq’s national government is refusing to take over thousands of reconstruction projects, a report shows.
snippet: Iraq’s national government is refusing to take over thousands of reconstruction projects, a report shows.
lead_paragraph: Iraq’s national government is refusing to take possession of thousands of American-financed reconstruction projects, forcing the United States either to hand them over to local Iraqis, who often lack the proper training and resources to keep the projects running, or commit new money to an effort that has already consumed billions of taxpayer dollars.

headline: British Pullback in Iraq Presages Hurdles for U.S.
print_headline: British Pullback In Iraq Presages Hurdles for U.S.
abstract: Skepticism is widespread in Basra, as in Baghdad, about whether Iraqi forces are ready to take over.
snippet: Skepticism is widespread in Basra, as in Baghdad, about whether Iraqi forces are ready to take over.
lead_paragraph: BASRA, Iraq — As American troop levels are peaking in Baghdad, British force levels are heading in the opposite direction as the troops prepare to withdraw completely from the city center of Basra, 300 miles to the south.

headline: Governing Party in Japan Suffers Election Defeat
print_headline: Governing Party In Japan Suffers Election Defeat

snippet: The opposition party seized control of the upper house, but Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said he would not step down.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Monday, July 30 — Japan’s governing Liberal Democratic Party suffered a crushing defeat Sunday in the election for the upper house of Parliament, but Prime Minister Shinzo Abe vowed that he would not step down.

headline: Safety Violations Cited for Deaths in Subway Work
print_headline: Safety Violations Cited for Deaths In Subway Work
abstract: Flawed safety procedures and lax “organizational culture” led to the deaths of two workers in April, reports found.
snippet: Flawed safety procedures and lax “organizational culture” led to the deaths of two workers in April, reports found.
lead_paragraph: The deaths of two subway workers in April resulted primarily from flawed safety procedures and a lax “organizational culture” in which track workers and supervisors flouted basic safety rules and failed to alert operators of oncoming trains to the presence of workers on the tracks, according to reports released yesterday by New York City Transit.

headline: Stunned Victim Turns Hero
print_headline: Stunned Victim Turns Hero in Busful of Children
abstract: A 20-year-old summer program gym coordinator played a key role in saving children in a trapped bus.
snippet: A 20-year-old summer program gym coordinator played a key role in saving children in a trapped bus.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 2 — By the time they reached the Interstate 35W bridge, the children on the bus were waterlogged and serene, some still in their bathing suits, ready to go home. It was a rare moment of quiet, and as the bus crossed over the Mississippi River a few of the counselors, barely out of adolescence themselves, had dropped off to sleep in their seats.

headline: Shooting of 4 College Friends Baffles Newark
print_headline: Shooting of 4, College Friends, Baffles Newark
abstract: The authorities were struggling to explain why three young friends were lined up and shot dead Saturday.
snippet: The authorities were struggling to explain why three young friends were lined up and shot dead Saturday.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK, Aug. 5 — The authorities were struggling to explain one of Newark’s most chilling slaughters in recent memory after three young friends were lined up against a schoolyard wall and shot dead late Saturday. A fourth person survived a gunshot.

headline: Tougher Rules Change Game for Lobbyists
print_headline: Tougher Rules Change Game For Lobbyists

snippet: Far-reaching ethics and lobbying rules passed by Congress have sent a ripple of fear through K Street.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 — H. Stewart Van Scoyoc, founder of one of the biggest lobbying firms in Washington, spent an anxious morning with his lawyer last week assessing the far-reaching ethics and lobbying rules Congress had passed the day before.

headline: Product Packages Now Shout to Get Your Attention

snippet: Consumer goods companies are using their products’ packages as 3-D ads to grab shoppers’ fickle attention.
lead_paragraph: In the last 100 years, Pepsi had changed the look of its can, and before that its bottles, only 10 times. This year alone, the soft-drink maker will switch designs every few weeks.

headline: Armstrong Team Falls With Cycling’s Image
print_headline: Armstrong’s Team Goes Down With Cycling’s Sinking Image

snippet: The crisis over doping has turned even Lance Armstrong into a pessimist about cycling’s short-term future.
lead_paragraph: The cycling team of Lance Armstrong and of this year’s Tour de France winner is disbanding for lack of a sponsor, the latest evidence that the sport is collapsing under the weight of persistent doping problems.

headline: Importing Chiefs, Detroit Reflects on Its ‘Car Guys’
print_headline: As Detroit Imports Executives, A City Reflects on Its ‘Car Guys’

snippet: As a former Home Depot chief heads Chrysler, Detroit has completed a new-model changeover of the executive suite.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Aug. 12 — Where have all the car guys gone?

headline: A Grass-Roots Effort to Grow Old at Home
print_headline: A Grass-Roots Effort to Grow Old at Home

snippet: Groups want to make neighborhoods comfortable places for elderly people not interested in assisted living.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On a bluff overlooking the Potomac River, George and Anne Allen, both 82, struggle to remain in their beloved three-story house and neighborhood, despite the frailty, danger and isolation of old age.

headline: New York to Get U.S. Traffic Aid, but With Catch
print_headline: New York to Get U.S. Traffic Aid, But With Catch

snippet: The federal government’s package for traffic reduction doesn’t pay for congestion pricing in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The federal government said on Tuesday that it would provide $354 million for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s broad plan to reduce traffic, but left it to the city to come up with more than $200 million needed for the most controversial part of the plan: a system to charge people who drive into Manhattan.

headline: With Markets Moving Wildly, Insight Suffers
print_headline: With Markets Moving Wildly, Insight Suffers
abstract: Why is the credit panic of 2007 being played out in slow motion? Information may arrive instantly, but insight takes longer.
snippet: Why is the credit panic of 2007 being played out in slow motion? Information may arrive instantly, but insight takes longer.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-first-century financial markets react with lightning speed to events halfway around the world. Investors in China can immediately see what happened in New York and make trades in London based on the news.

headline: Utah Mine Rescuers Halt Search After 3 Deaths
print_headline: Grim Mine Rescuers Halt Search After 3 Deaths

snippet: A sense of doleful finality has settled over the quivering mountain that swallowed six miners 11 days ago.
lead_paragraph: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 17 — A sense of doleful finality settled on Friday over the quivering mountain here that swallowed six coal miners 11 days ago.

headline: Falluja’s Calm Is Seen as Fragile if U.S. Leaves
print_headline: Falluja’s Calm Is Seen at Risk If U.S. Leaves
abstract: Western Iraq’s improved security, often cited as a success story, could be undermined as the Marines withdraw.
snippet: Western Iraq’s improved security, often cited as a success story, could be undermined as the Marines withdraw.
lead_paragraph: FALLUJA, Iraq — Falluja’s police chief, Col. Faisal Ismail Hussein, waved aloft a picture of a severed head in a bucket as a reminder of the brutality of the fundamentalist Sunni militias that once controlled this city. But he also described an uncertain future without “my only supporters,” the United States Marine Corps.

headline: Bid to Reopen Mine Divides Grieving Utah Town
print_headline: Bid to Reopen Mine Divides Grieving Town

snippet: Officials said the mine where six workers were trapped could resume operating with a new name.
lead_paragraph: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 21 — As relatives on Tuesday laid to rest one of three men killed here trying to rescue six trapped miners, this grieving mining town was torn over the future of the mine and the prospect of the lost miners’ being entombed permanently.

headline: Rule to Expand Mountaintop Coal Mining
print_headline: Rule to Expand Mountaintop Coal Mining
abstract: The Bush administration is set to issue a regulation to enshrine a method of blasting off the tops of mountains.
snippet: The Bush administration is set to issue a regulation to enshrine a method of blasting off the tops of mountains.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 — The Bush administration is set to issue a regulation on Friday that would enshrine the coal mining practice of mountaintop removal. The technique involves blasting off the tops of mountains and dumping the rubble into valleys and streams.

headline: Chinese Seek to Buy a U.S. Maker of Disk Drives
print_headline: Chinese Seek A U.S. Maker Of Disk Drives
abstract: The overture for Seagate Technology has raised concerns among American officials about risks to national security.
snippet: The overture for Seagate Technology has raised concerns among American officials about risks to national security.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24 — A Chinese technology company has expressed interest in buying a maker of computer disk drives in the United States, raising concerns among American government officials about the risks to national security in transferring high technology to China.

headline: Drop Foreseen in Median Price of U.S. Homes
print_headline: DROP FORESEEN IN MEDIAN PRICE OF HOMES IN U.S.
abstract: Many government officials and housing-industry executives had said that a nationwide decline would never happen.
snippet: Many government officials and housing-industry executives had said that a nationwide decline would never happen.
lead_paragraph: The median price of American homes is expected to fall this year for the first time since federal housing agencies began keeping statistics in 1950.

headline: Past 50, and Still Running Into the Flames
print_headline: Past 50, and Still Running Into the Flames
abstract: Robert Beddia, who died at the Deutsche Bank skyscraper, was one of 502 firefighters over 50 on a force of 9,090.
snippet: Robert Beddia, who died at the Deutsche Bank skyscraper, was one of 502 firefighters over 50 on a force of 9,090.
lead_paragraph: There was a two-digit footnote to tragedy tucked behind the name of a fallen firefighter, Robert Beddia, who died Aug. 18 in the blaze at the Deutsche Bank skyscraper at ground zero. It was his age.

headline: Pakistani Leader to Exit Army Job, His Rival Reports
print_headline: PAKISTANI LEADER TO EXIT ARMY JOB, HIS RIVAL REPORTS
abstract: Gen. Pervez Musharraf would resign as army chief and serve another term as president and former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto would return to Pakistan.
snippet: Gen. Pervez Musharraf would resign as army chief and serve another term as president and former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto would return to Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 29 — The exiled former prime minister Benazir Bhutto said Wednesday that Pakistan’s president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, had agreed to resign as army chief as part of a nearly completed deal that would allow him to serve another term as president if he is re-elected and allow her to return to Pakistan to run for prime minister.

headline: At I.B.M., a Vacation Anytime, or Maybe None
print_headline: At I.B.M., a Vacation Anytime, Or Maybe No Vacation at All
abstract: I.B.M. is probably the largest company to do away with tracking vacation.
snippet: I.B.M. is probably the largest company to do away with tracking vacation.
lead_paragraph: SOMERS, N.Y. — It’s every worker’s dream: take as much vacation time as you want, on short notice, and don’t worry about your boss calling you on it. Cut out early, make it a long weekend, string two weeks together — as you like. No need to call in sick on a Friday so you can disappear for a fishing trip. Just go; nobody’s keeping track.

headline: A Football Goliath Faced a Proud, Talented David
print_headline: A Football Goliath, Michigan Faced a Proud, Talented David
abstract: Appalachian State’s stunning upset of Michigan was not as great a shock to those who have followed the I-AA team.
snippet: Appalachian State’s stunning upset of Michigan was not as great a shock to those who have followed the I-AA team.
lead_paragraph: BOONE, N.C., Sept. 2 — There used to be a running joke in North Carolina that the best college football team in the state could not be found at any of those esteemed campuses with basketball traditions in Chapel Hill, Durham or Raleigh. You had to go to a small resort town in the Blue Ridge Mountains named after Daniel Boone to find North Carolina’s top program.

headline: Bush, in Iraq, Says Troop Reduction Is Possible
print_headline: Bush, in Iraq, Says Troop Reduction Is Possible
abstract: President Bush pre-empted pressure for a withdrawal by hailing what he called successes and contending that only a stable Iraq would allow a U.S. pullback.
snippet: President Bush pre-empted pressure for a withdrawal by hailing what he called successes and contending that only a stable Iraq would allow a U.S. pullback.
lead_paragraph: AL ASAD AIR BASE, Iraq, Sept. 3 — President Bush made a surprise eight-hour visit to Iraq on Monday, emphasizing security gains, sectarian reconciliation and the possibility of a troop withdrawal, thus embracing and pre-empting this month’s crucial Congressional hearings on his Iraq strategy.

headline: Despite DNA Test, a Case Is Retried
print_headline: Despite DNA Result, Prosecutor Retries a ’92 Rape-Murder Case
abstract: Prosecutors in Mississippi have sought a new capital murder trial after DNA evidence overturned a conviction.
snippet: Prosecutors in Mississippi have sought a new capital murder trial after DNA evidence overturned a conviction.
lead_paragraph: MACON, Miss., Aug. 31 — The scene in the tiny Noxubee County jail on a rainy afternoon has become almost commonplace. Kennedy Brewer, sentenced to death and locked up for 15 years for the rape and murder of a 3-year-old, was released on the strength of a DNA test showing that the semen in the rape kit was not his.

headline: Accuracy of 9/11 Health Reports Is Questioned
print_headline:
CONDITION UNCERTAIN
One Small Clinic | Accuracy of 9/11 Health Reports Is Questioned
abstract: A small clinic that handled the cases of thousands of 9/11 recovery and cleanup workers is coming under scrutiny.
snippet: A small clinic that handled the cases of thousands of 9/11 recovery and cleanup workers is coming under scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: Much of what is known about the health problems of ground zero workers comes from a small clinic in Manhattan that at the time of the trade center collapse had only six full-time doctors and a tiny budget.

headline: Romney’s Tone on Gay Rights Is Seen as Shift
print_headline: Romney’s Tone On Gay Rights Is Seen as Shift
abstract: The presidential candidate bristles when he is accused of shifting his views since his 2002 campaign for governor of Massachusetts.
snippet: The presidential candidate bristles when he is accused of shifting his views since his 2002 campaign for governor of Massachusetts.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney seemed comfortable as a group of gay Republicans quizzed him over breakfast one morning in 2002. Running for governor of Massachusetts, he was at a gay bar in Boston to court members of Log Cabin Republicans.

headline: Still Married, With Children, but in Russian
print_headline: Still Married, With Children, But Trading Insults in Russian
abstract: Despite the Kremlin’s drumbeat of anti-Americanism, Russians have embraced imports of American sitcoms.
snippet: Despite the Kremlin’s drumbeat of anti-Americanism, Russians have embraced imports of American sitcoms.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Sept. 9 — Turn on the sitcom that is the hottest television show in Russia, and it all seems so familiar. Moored to his living room couch is a shoe salesman who is more interested in watching sports than conjugal relations. His wife has shocking hair and an even more shocking mouth. A couple of ne’er-do-well teenagers round out this bawdy, bickering bunch.

headline: Petraeus Warns Against Quick Pullback in Iraq
print_headline: Petraeus Warns Against Quick Pullback in Iraq
abstract: Gen. David H. Petraeus said that by next summer the U.S. should be able to reduce its troop strength in Iraq to the level it was at before the recent increase.
snippet: Gen. David H. Petraeus said that by next summer the U.S. should be able to reduce its troop strength in Iraq to the level it was at before the recent increase.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 — Gen. David H. Petraeus, the senior American commander in Iraq, warned in stark terms against the kind of rapid pullback favored by the Democratic majorities in the House and Senate, in a day of testimony on Monday that drove home the continuing inability of the Democrats to force a change in strategy in Iraq.

headline: Bush Nearing Choice to Lead Justice Dept.
print_headline: BUSH IS NEARING A CHOICE TO LEAD THE JUSTICE DEPT.
abstract: Former Solicitor General Theodore B. Olson, seen as a staunch partisan, is considered a top candidate.
snippet: Former Solicitor General Theodore B. Olson, seen as a staunch partisan, is considered a top candidate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 — The White House is closing in on a nominee to replace Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales, with former Solicitor General Theodore B. Olson considered one of the leading candidates, administration and Congressional officials said Tuesday.

headline: Former Fed Chief Attacks Bush on Fiscal Role
print_headline: Fed’s Ex-Chief Attacks Bush On Fiscal Role
abstract: In his memoir, Alan Greenspan is critical of Republicans for abandoning their principles on spending and deficits.
snippet: In his memoir, Alan Greenspan is critical of Republicans for abandoning their principles on spending and deficits.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 — Alan Greenspan, who was chairman of the Federal Reserve for nearly two decades, in a long-awaited memoir, is harshly critical of President Bush, Vice President Dick Cheney and the Republican-controlled Congress, as abandoning their party’s principles on spending and deficits.

headline: In Turnaround, Industries Seek U.S. Regulations
print_headline: In Turnaround, Industries Seek U.S. Regulations
abstract: Trying to fend off lawsuits, foreign competition and state rules, some big industries are pushing for new federal regulations.
snippet: Trying to fend off lawsuits, foreign competition and state rules, some big industries are pushing for new federal regulations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 — After years of favoring the hands-off doctrine of the Bush administration, some of the nation’s biggest industries are pushing for something they have long resisted: new federal regulations.

headline: Isolation of Gaza Chokes Off Trade
print_headline: Isolated, Gaza Traders Wither, Both Underground and Above
abstract: With Gaza almost entirely shut off from normal trade, Palestinian businesses are enduring a deep depression.
snippet: With Gaza almost entirely shut off from normal trade, Palestinian businesses are enduring a deep depression.
lead_paragraph: KARNI CROSSING, Gaza — One man runs a large clothing business started by his mother. The other runs an illegal smuggling business started by his father. One deals in clothes, the other in weapons and explosives.

headline: NBC to Offer Downloads of Its Shows
print_headline: NBC Will Offer Its Shows Free For Downloads
abstract: NBC Universal announced plans for a service to make popular NBC programs available free for computers and other devices.
snippet: NBC Universal announced plans for a service to make popular NBC programs available free for computers and other devices.
lead_paragraph: NBC Universal said yesterday that it would soon permit consumers to download many of NBC’s most popular programs free to personal computers and other devices for one week immediately after their broadcasts.

headline: Nuance and Resolve in Rulings by Attorney General Nominee
print_headline: Nuance and Resolve in Rulings By Attorney General Nominee
abstract: A look at 18 years of Judge Michael B. Mukasey’s opinions reveals a complex temperament and legal philosophy.
snippet: A look at 18 years of Judge Michael B. Mukasey’s opinions reveals a complex temperament and legal philosophy.
lead_paragraph: In his 18 years on the federal bench, Judge Michael B. Mukasey issued more than 1,500 decisions concerning matters as cataclysmic as the Holocaust and as mundane as milk, beer and cigarettes.

headline: Glimpses of a Shadowy World in Pakistan
print_headline: In Terror Detention, Glimpses Of Shadowy World in Pakistan
abstract: The arrest of a Pakistani-born German citizen offers glimpses of the traffic into the tribal areas of Pakistan and the attempt by the authorities to monitor it.
snippet: The arrest of a Pakistani-born German citizen offers glimpses of the traffic into the tribal areas of Pakistan and the attempt by the authorities to monitor it.
lead_paragraph: STUTTGART, Germany, Sept. 17 — Aleem Nasir, a 45-year-old German citizen who was held for two months this summer in Pakistan and interrogated by Pakistani and Western agents about terrorism-related activities, concedes that “they have their right to be worried about me.”

headline: Myanmar Raids Monasteries Before Dawn
print_headline: Myanmar Attacks Protesters, Arresting Monks
abstract: Security forces in Myanmar went into at least two Buddhist monasteries early today, beating and arresting dozens of monks.
snippet: Security forces in Myanmar went into at least two Buddhist monasteries early today, beating and arresting dozens of monks.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK, Sept. 27 — Beginning the second day of their crackdown on nationwide protests in Myanmar before dawn today, security forces raided at least two Buddhist monasteries, beating and arresting dozens of monks, according to reports from the capital, Yangon.

headline: New Test Asks: What Does ‘American’ Mean?
print_headline: Tough Question for a New Test: What Does ‘American’ Mean?
abstract: Authorities unveiled 100 new questions that immigrants will have to study to become American citizens.
snippet: Authorities unveiled 100 new questions that immigrants will have to study to become American citizens.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Henry and Francis Scott Key are out, but Susan B. Anthony and Nancy Pelosi are in. The White House was cut, but New York and Sept. 11 made the list.

headline: Exoneration Using DNA Brings Change in Legal System
print_headline: DNA Exoneration Leads to Change In Legal System
abstract: All but eight states now give inmates access to DNA evidence that might not have been available at the time of their convictions.
snippet: All but eight states now give inmates access to DNA evidence that might not have been available at the time of their convictions.
lead_paragraph: State lawmakers across the country are adopting broad changes to criminal justice procedures as a response to the exoneration of more than 200 convicts through the use of DNA evidence.

headline: Write-Downs by Big Banks Spark Rally
print_headline: Banks Admit Loan Losses; Stocks Rally
abstract: Wall Street’s banking giants started to admit their problems, and investors took the disclosures as a sign that the worst may be over.
snippet: Wall Street’s banking giants started to admit their problems, and investors took the disclosures as a sign that the worst may be over.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s banking giants started yesterday to admit their problems, which began in the mortgage lending business and led to a summer of wild stock market swings.

headline: Monks Are Silenced, and for Now, Internet Is, Too
print_headline: Monks Are Silenced, and for Now, the Web Is, Too
abstract: After smuggled images jeopardized their crackdown on demonstrators, Myanmar’s generals cut off the Internet.
snippet: After smuggled images jeopardized their crackdown on demonstrators, Myanmar’s generals cut off the Internet.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK, Oct. 3 — It was about as simple and uncomplicated as shooting demonstrators in the streets. Embarrassed by smuggled video and photographs that showed their people rising up against them, the generals who run Myanmar simply switched off the Internet.

headline: Olympic Champion Acknowledges Use of Steroids
print_headline: In Plea, Track Star Will Admit To Using Steroids, Lawyers Say
abstract: Marion Jones is expected to plead guilty to lying to federal agents about her use of steroids, two attorneys said.
snippet: Marion Jones is expected to plead guilty to lying to federal agents about her use of steroids, two attorneys said.
lead_paragraph: The former track star Marion Jones, one of the most accomplished female athletes in the world, is expected to plead guilty today to lying to federal agents about her use of performance-enhancing drugs, two lawyers connected with the case said yesterday. The admission would end years of denial and would likely lead to her being stripped of the record five medals she won in the 2000 Olympics in Sydney, Australia.

headline: Life of Comfort and Pain Ends in an Airport Cell
print_headline: Life of Comfort and Pain Ends in an Airport Cell
abstract: Behind Carol Gotbaum’s death in custody of the Phoenix police is a story of a wife and mother fighting her demons.
snippet: Behind Carol Gotbaum’s death in custody of the Phoenix police is a story of a wife and mother fighting her demons.
lead_paragraph: Last Nov. 1, Noah Gotbaum phoned his father and stepmother to say that he had just discovered his wife, Carol, drunk and passed out in their town house on West 95th Street. An ambulance, he told them, was rushing her to St. Luke’s-Roosevelt Hospital Center.

headline:
Britain to Halve 
Its Force in Iraq
print_headline: Britain to Halve Its Force in Iraq By Spring of ’08
abstract: The move suggests that the alliance on Iraq forged between former Prime Minister Tony Blair and Washington is unraveling.
snippet: The move suggests that the alliance on Iraq forged between former Prime Minister Tony Blair and Washington is unraveling.
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Oct. 8 — Prime Minister Gordon Brown told the House of Commons on Monday that he would remove half of the 5,000 British troops in Iraq by next spring, and left open the strong possibility that all British soldiers would leave Iraq by the end of 2008.

headline: Romney and Giuliani Spar as New Guy Looks On
print_headline: Romney and Giuliani Spar as New Guy Looks On
abstract: The debate marked the debut of Fred D. Thompson, who often found himself a bystander as Rudolph W. Giuliani and Mitt Romney attacked each other.
snippet: The debate marked the debut of Fred D. Thompson, who often found himself a bystander as Rudolph W. Giuliani and Mitt Romney attacked each other.
lead_paragraph: Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York and Mitt Romney of Massachusetts tangled over taxes and government spending yesterday as the Republican presidential candidates debated in Michigan, highlighting the way in which their increasingly fierce confrontation is starting to dominate the race for their party’s nomination.

headline: Nobel to Lessing, Incisive Voice of Women’s Fate
print_headline: Nobel to Lessing, Incisive Voice of Women’s Fate
abstract: Doris Lessing, the novelist whose deeply autobiographical writing has swept across continents and reflects her engagement with the social and political issues of her time, won the 2007 Nobel Prize in Literature.
snippet: Doris Lessing, the novelist whose deeply autobiographical writing has swept across continents and reflects her engagement with the social and political issues of her time, won the 2007 Nobel Prize in Literature.
lead_paragraph: Doris Lessing, the Persian-born, Rhodesian-raised and London-residing novelist whose deeply autobiographical writing has swept across continents and reflects her engagement with the social and political issues of her time, yesterday won the 2007 Nobel Prize in Literature.

headline: Voting Machines Giving Florida New Headache
print_headline: Vote Machines Giving Florida New Headache
abstract: Touch screens bought after 2000 have now been deemed failures and must be replaced with optical-scan machines.
snippet: Touch screens bought after 2000 have now been deemed failures and must be replaced with optical-scan machines.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI, Oct. 12 — It used to be that everyone wanted a Florida voting machine.

headline: At an Army School for Officers, Blunt Talk About Iraq
print_headline: At an Army School for Officers, Blunt Talk About Iraq Strategy
abstract: Fort Leavenworth, Kan., the intellectual center of the U.S. Army, has become a front line in the military’s soul-searching over Iraq.
snippet: Fort Leavenworth, Kan., the intellectual center of the U.S. Army, has become a front line in the military’s soul-searching over Iraq.
lead_paragraph: FORT LEAVENWORTH, Kan. — Here at the intellectual center of the United States Army, two elite officers were deep in debate at lunch on a recent day over who bore more responsibility for mistakes in Iraq — the former defense secretary, Donald H. Rumsfeld, or the generals who acquiesced to him.

headline: Support Wanes in House for Genocide Vote
print_headline: AS TURKS OBJECT, GENOCIDE MOTION FALTERS IN HOUSE
abstract: The Turkish government has said House passage of the resolution would prompt it to reconsider its ties to the United States, including logistical support for the Iraq war.
snippet: The Turkish government has said House passage of the resolution would prompt it to reconsider its ties to the United States, including logistical support for the Iraq war.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 — Worried about antagonizing Turkish leaders, House members from both parties have begun to withdraw their support from a resolution backed by the Democratic leadership that would condemn as genocide the mass killings of Armenians nearly a century ago.

headline: Iraqi Contracts With Iran and China Concern U.S.
print_headline: U.S. Concerned as Iraq Awards Power Deals to Iran and China
abstract: American officials fear that commercial investments in Iraqi power plants could mask military activities by Iran.
snippet: American officials fear that commercial investments in Iraqi power plants could mask military activities by Iran.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Oct. 17 — Iraq has agreed to award $1.1 billion in contracts to Iranian and Chinese companies to build a pair of enormous power plants, the Iraqi electricity minister said Tuesday. Word of the project prompted serious concerns among American military officials, who fear that Iranian commercial investments can mask military activities at a time of heightened tension with Iran.

headline: His Meteoric Days Gone, Quiet Dean Leads Party
print_headline: His Meteoric Days Behind Him, A Less Fiery Dean Leads Party
abstract: Four years after his rise and fall, Howard Dean is happy to conduct the Democrats’ business in near obscurity.
snippet: Four years after his rise and fall, Howard Dean is happy to conduct the Democrats’ business in near obscurity.
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL, Oct. 16 — There has never been a Democratic chairman with as much firsthand knowledge about running for president as Howard Dean.

headline: A Son of Immigrants Rises in a Southern State
print_headline: A Son of Immigrants Rises In a Deeply Southern State
abstract: Bobby Jindal will be the nation’s first Indian-American governor in a state where race is inseparable from politics.
snippet: Bobby Jindal will be the nation’s first Indian-American governor in a state where race is inseparable from politics.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 21 — The first words from Bobby Jindal to his supporters after he won the Louisiana governor’s race on Saturday night were not about his victory, but L.S.U.’s triumph over Auburn the same day.

headline: Mideast Hawks Help to Develop Giuliani Policy
print_headline: Mideast Hawks Help to Develop Giuliani Policy
abstract: Rudolph W. Giuliani is consulting with a particularly hawkish group of advisers and neoconservative thinkers.
snippet: Rudolph W. Giuliani is consulting with a particularly hawkish group of advisers and neoconservative thinkers.
lead_paragraph: Rudolph W. Giuliani’s approach to foreign policy shares with other Republican presidential candidates an aggressive posture toward terrorism, a commitment to strengthening the military and disdain for the United Nations.

headline: President Visits Scene and Promises Help
print_headline: President Visits Scene of Fires, Promising Help
abstract: President Bush toured fire-ravaged Southern California as the threat began to ebb and the focus shifted to the investigation of possible arson.
snippet: President Bush toured fire-ravaged Southern California as the threat began to ebb and the focus shifted to the investigation of possible arson.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 — President Bush toured Southern California on Thursday as investigators got down to the work of determining how one sunny fall day last weekend erupted into a 16-fire storm now in its fifth day.

headline: Risk-Taker’s Reign at Merrill Ends With Swift Fall
print_headline: A Risk-Taker’s Reign at Merrill Ends With a Swift, Messy Fall
abstract: E. Stanley O’Neal is expected to resign as early as Monday as chairman and chief executive of Merrill Lynch.
snippet: E. Stanley O’Neal is expected to resign as early as Monday as chairman and chief executive of Merrill Lynch.
lead_paragraph: The six-year reign of E. Stanley O’Neal at Merrill Lynch has been one of contradictions. He was a loner in an industry that places a premium on relationships. And he pushed Merrill into risky investments despite his experience as chief financial officer, where assessing risk was one of his responsibilities.

headline: Immunity Deals Offered to Blackwater Guards
print_headline: STATE DEPT. MADE IMMUNITY OFFER TO FIRM’S GUARDS
abstract: Officials said that State Department investigators lacked the authority to offer the deals.
snippet: Officials said that State Department investigators lacked the authority to offer the deals.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 — State Department investigators offered Blackwater USA security guards immunity during an inquiry into last month’s deadly shooting of 17 Iraqis in Baghdad — a potentially serious investigative misstep that could complicate efforts to prosecute the company’s employees involved in the episode, government officials said Monday.

headline: Bush, Defending Justice Nominee, Sees Unfairness
print_headline: BUSH, DEFENDING JUSTICE NOMINEE, SEES UNFAIRNESS
abstract: Caught off guard by the fight over Michael B. Mukasey, the White House has begun a campaign to salvage his candidacy.
snippet: Caught off guard by the fight over Michael B. Mukasey, the White House has begun a campaign to salvage his candidacy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 — The White House began a campaign Thursday to save the candidacy of Michael B. Mukasey for attorney general, with President Bush defending him in a speech and in an Oval Office interview, where he complained that Mr. Mukasey was “not being treated fairly” on Capitol Hill.

headline: As Japan Ages, Prisons Adapt to Going Gray
print_headline: As Japan Ages, Prisons Adapt To Going Gray
abstract: With one of the world’s most rapidly aging societies, Japan is confronting a sharp increase in older prisoners.
snippet: With one of the world’s most rapidly aging societies, Japan is confronting a sharp increase in older prisoners.
lead_paragraph: ONOMICHI, Japan — In the prison’s brightly lighted workroom here, 47 inmates sat behind long tables and quietly performed their chores.

headline: Fixing Citigroup Will Test Rubin
print_headline: Fixing Citigroup Will Test Rubin
abstract: Robert E. Rubin, named chairman of Citigroup, will seek to revive the troubled bank, which said it would take an additional $8 billion to $11 billion write-down.
snippet: Robert E. Rubin, named chairman of Citigroup, will seek to revive the troubled bank, which said it would take an additional $8 billion to $11 billion write-down.
lead_paragraph: Throughout a long, public career, Robert E. Rubin spanned the highest reaches of Wall Street and Washington, and succeeded wherever he went.

headline: 50 New York Schools Fail Under Rating System
print_headline: 50 City Schools Get Failing Grade In a New System
abstract: The schools that failed in a blunt new rating system were so dismal that their 29,000 students would be allowed to transfer elsewhere, said Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.
snippet: The schools that failed in a blunt new rating system were so dismal that their 29,000 students would be allowed to transfer elsewhere, said Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.
lead_paragraph: Under a blunt new A through F rating system that judges schools not just on performance but also on progress, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg designated 50 New York City public schools as failures yesterday, saying they were so dismal that their 29,000 students would be allowed to transfer elsewhere.

headline: Republicans Join Vote to Override Water Bill Veto
print_headline: Republicans Join Vote To Override Water Bill Veto
abstract: A majority of House Republicans joined Democrats on Tuesday in confronting President Bush over federal spending.
snippet: A majority of House Republicans joined Democrats on Tuesday in confronting President Bush over federal spending.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 — Congressional Democrats escalated a confrontation with President Bush over federal spending on Tuesday as the House overrode Mr. Bush’s veto of a popular water projects measure and approved a $215 billion bill to pay for health, education, labor and veterans programs despite a veto threat.

headline: Mukasey Wins Vote in Senate, Despite Doubts
print_headline: Mukasey Wins Vote in Senate, Despite Doubts
abstract: Michael B. Mukasey was confirmed despite Democratic criticism of his position on interrogation methods.
snippet: Michael B. Mukasey was confirmed despite Democratic criticism of his position on interrogation methods.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 — The Senate confirmed Michael B. Mukasey as attorney general Thursday night, approving him despite Democratic criticism that he had failed to take an unequivocal stance against the torture of terrorism detainees.

headline: Bush and Relatives of Fallen Lean on Each Other
print_headline: Bush and Relatives of Fallen Lean on Each Other
abstract: In the past six years, President Bush has met hundreds of bereaved military families in deeply private sessions.
snippet: In the past six years, President Bush has met hundreds of bereaved military families in deeply private sessions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 — Late one night last year, while her husband was an Army scout in Iraq, Melissa Storey sat in the quiet of her bedroom to write President Bush a letter. She wanted him to know “we believed in him.” And after Staff Sgt. Clint Storey, 30, was killed by a roadside bomb, his widow put pen to paper again.

headline: As Stagehands Strike, Broadway Shows Don’t Go On
print_headline: As Stagehands Strike, Shows Don’t Go On
abstract: After months of negotiations, a strike will shut down all but eight Broadway shows.
snippet: After months of negotiations, a strike will shut down all but eight Broadway shows.
lead_paragraph: Most of Broadway was dark yesterday as stagehands went on strike over new work rules that producers have imposed or have been pushing during months of contentious negotiations.

headline: Spitzer Dropping His Driver’s License Plan
print_headline: Spitzer Dropping His License Plan
abstract: Gov. Eliot Spitzer said opposition to his proposal to issue licenses to illegal immigrants has been too overwhelming.
snippet: Gov. Eliot Spitzer said opposition to his proposal to issue licenses to illegal immigrants has been too overwhelming.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, Nov. 13 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer is abandoning his plan to issue driver’s licenses to illegal immigrants, saying that opposition is just too overwhelming to move forward with such a policy.

headline: African Crucible: Cast as Witches, Then Cast Out
print_headline: African Crucible: Cast as Witches, Then Cast Out
abstract: A surprising number of children in some countries are identified as witches and beaten, abused or abandoned.
snippet: A surprising number of children in some countries are identified as witches and beaten, abused or abandoned.
lead_paragraph: UIGE, Angola — Domingos Pedro was only 12 years old when his father died. The passing was sudden; the cause was a mystery to doctors. But not to Domingos’s relatives.

headline: Immigration Quandary: A Mother Torn From Her Baby
print_headline: Case of Mother Torn From Baby Reflects Immigration Quandary
abstract: A mother’s separation from a breast-feeding child, a U.S. citizen, has prompted changes to immigration guidelines.
snippet: A mother’s separation from a breast-feeding child, a U.S. citizen, has prompted changes to immigration guidelines.
lead_paragraph: Federal immigration agents were searching a house in Ohio last month when they found a young Honduran woman nursing her baby.

headline: U.S. Secretly Aids Pakistan in Guarding Nuclear Arms
print_headline: U.S. Secretly Aids Pakistan In Guarding Nuclear Arms
abstract: Debate is growing about whether an American classified program has done enough to help protect Pakistan’s nuclear weapons.
snippet: Debate is growing about whether an American classified program has done enough to help protect Pakistan’s nuclear weapons.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 — Over the past six years, the Bush administration has spent almost $100 million on a highly classified program to help Gen. Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan’s president, secure his country’s nuclear weapons, according to current and former senior administration officials.

headline: Goldman Sachs Rakes In Profit in Credit Crisis
print_headline: Wall St. Firm Rakes In Profit In Credit Crisis
abstract: Rarely on Wall Street, where money travels in herds, has one firm gotten it so right when nearly everyone else was getting it so wrong.
snippet: Rarely on Wall Street, where money travels in herds, has one firm gotten it so right when nearly everyone else was getting it so wrong.
lead_paragraph: For more than three months, as turmoil in the credit market has swept wildly through Wall Street, one mighty investment bank after another has been brought to its knees, leveled by multibillion-dollar blows to their bottom lines.

headline: Foreign Fighters in Iraq Are Tied to Allies of U.S.
print_headline: Foreign Fighters in Iraq Are Tied to Allies of U.S.
abstract: Saudi Arabia and Libya were the source of about 60 percent of the foreign fighters who came to Iraq in the past year to facilitate attacks.
snippet: Saudi Arabia and Libya were the source of about 60 percent of the foreign fighters who came to Iraq in the past year to facilitate attacks.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Saudi Arabia and Libya, both considered allies by the United States in its fight against terrorism, were the source of about 60 percent of the foreign fighters who came to Iraq in the past year to serve as suicide bombers or to facilitate other attacks, according to senior American military officials.

headline: Where the Votes Are, So Are All Those Calories
print_headline: Where the Votes Are, So, Unfortunately, Are All Those Calories
abstract: Presidential candidates frequently find themselves obliged to change their eating habits on the campaign trail.
snippet: Presidential candidates frequently find themselves obliged to change their eating habits on the campaign trail.
lead_paragraph: Running for president is like entering a competitive eating contest and a beauty pageant all at once. Candidates are expected to eat local specialties often and with gusto, yet still look attractive and fit.

headline: New York Manhole Covers, Forged Barefoot in India
print_headline: New York Manhole Covers, Forged Barefoot and Sweaty in India
abstract: Foundry workers have few protections as they make manhole covers for Con Edison and a city department.
snippet: Foundry workers have few protections as they make manhole covers for Con Edison and a city department.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Eight thousand miles from Manhattan, barefoot, shirtless, whip-thin men rippled with muscle were forging prosaic pieces of the urban jigsaw puzzle: manhole covers.

headline: In Hospice Care, Longer Lives Mean Money Lost
print_headline: In Hospice Care, Longer Lives Mean Money Lost
abstract: With patients living longer, the government is making hospices repay hundreds of millions of dollars to Medicare.
snippet: With patients living longer, the government is making hospices repay hundreds of millions of dollars to Medicare.
lead_paragraph: CAMDEN, Ala. — Hundreds of hospice providers across the country are facing the catastrophic financial consequence of what would otherwise seem a positive development: their patients are living longer than expected.

headline: Polishing Sets and Lines, Broadway Comes Back
print_headline: Polishing Sets and Lines, Broadway Comes Back
abstract: After a strike that shut down Broadway theaters for 19 days, some shows raced the clock to get the curtain up.
snippet: After a strike that shut down Broadway theaters for 19 days, some shows raced the clock to get the curtain up.
lead_paragraph: At “Chicago,” the cast had to do a run-through because the new leading man and two other stars joining the show — Vincent Pastore and Aida Turturro, of “The Sopranos” — had never rehearsed together.

headline: Putin’s Last Realm to Conquer: Russian Culture
print_headline: Putin’s Last Realm to Conquer: Russian Culture
abstract: A Kremlin that has gained authority over business and government may be setting its sights on artistic freedom.
snippet: A Kremlin that has gained authority over business and government may be setting its sights on artistic freedom.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The fight is long over here for authority over the security services, the oil business, mass media and pretty much all the levers of government. Vladimir Putin’s Kremlin, notwithstanding some recent anti-government protests, has won those wars, hands down, and promises to consolidate its position in parliamentary elections. But now there is concern that the Kremlin is setting its sights on Russian culture.

headline: Venezuela Hands Narrow Defeat to Chávez Plan
print_headline: Venezuela Hands Narrow Defeat To Chávez Plan
abstract: The results of a referendum that would have given new powers to President Hugo Chávez were a stunning development in a country where he controls nearly all the levers of power.
snippet: The results of a referendum that would have given new powers to President Hugo Chávez were a stunning development in a country where he controls nearly all the levers of power.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela, Monday, Dec. 3 — Voters in this country narrowly defeated a proposed overhaul to the constitution in a contentious referendum over granting President Hugo Chávez sweeping new powers, the Election Commission announced early Monday.

headline: Vulnerable Democrats See Fates Tied to Clinton
print_headline: Vulnerable House Democrats See Fates Tied to a Clinton Run
abstract: Some House Democrats are concerned over the possibility that Hillary Rodham Clinton will be their party nominee.
snippet: Some House Democrats are concerned over the possibility that Hillary Rodham Clinton will be their party nominee.
lead_paragraph: MANHATTAN, Kan. — Nancy Boyda, a Democrat who ran for Congress in this district last year, owed her upset victory partly to the popularity of the Democratic woman at the top of the ticket: Kathleen Sebelius, who won the governor’s seat. Now, with a tough re-election race at hand in 2008, Ms. Boyda faces the prospect that her electoral fate could be tied to another woman: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Comedian Says Minnesota Run Is a Serious One
print_headline: Comedian Says Minnesota Run Is a Serious One
abstract: Al Franken, the former “Saturday Night Live” star, is performing a balancing act as he runs for the U.S. Senate.
snippet: Al Franken, the former “Saturday Night Live” star, is performing a balancing act as he runs for the U.S. Senate.
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL  Even as Al Franken stretches out his big doughy hand to another potential voter inside Nina’s Coffee Cafe on a recent morning, it is easy to forget that Mr. Franken, the former “Saturday Night Live” star, the satirist and author, the liberal radio host, is trying to be elected to the United States Senate.

headline: The Roles Blur for the Mayor and the Mogul
print_headline: The Roles Blur For the Mayor And the Mogul
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s wealth and sprawling business interests make him a novel mayor.
snippet: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s wealth and sprawling business interests make him a novel mayor.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has frequently turned to Deputy Mayor Daniel L. Doctoroff to handle city matters that the mayor should avoid, given his extensive business interests.

headline: College Loans by States Face Fresh Scrutiny
print_headline: College Loans By States Face Fresh Scrutiny
abstract: Officials accuse some state-affiliated student loan corporations of having forgotten their purpose.
snippet: Officials accuse some state-affiliated student loan corporations of having forgotten their purpose.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES  When Iowa set up a corporation to make student loans more available, it hoped to expand access to college. Now state officials are investigating whether the corporation’s aggressive practices to get business help explain why Iowa’s college graduates have the nation’s second-highest debt burden per student.

headline: President Pick Would Name Putin Premier
print_headline: Putin’s Choice Moves to Keep Putin in Power
abstract: If the scenario outlined by Dmitri A. Medvedev plays out, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia would still wield power.
snippet: If the scenario outlined by Dmitri A. Medvedev plays out, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia would still wield power.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  The longtime aide tapped by Vladimir V. Putin to be his successor as president of Russia declared Tuesday that he wanted Mr. Putin to be his prime minister, offering the clearest indication yet of how Mr. Putin plans to maintain firm control over the Kremlin after his term ends next spring.

headline: Central Bankers to Lend Billions in Credit Crisis
print_headline: CENTRAL BANKERS TO LEND BILLIONS IN CREDIT CRISIS
abstract: Led by the Fed, five central banks announced an aggressive infusion of capital into the banking system, hoping to ease the credit crunch.
snippet: Led by the Fed, five central banks announced an aggressive infusion of capital into the banking system, hoping to ease the credit crunch.
lead_paragraph: A day after the Federal Reserve disappointed investors with a modest cut in interest rates, central banks in North America and Europe on Wednesday announced the most aggressive infusion of capital into the banking system since the terrorist attacks of September 2001.

headline: Climate Plan Looks Beyond Bush’s Tenure
print_headline: Climate Plan Looks Beyond Bush’s Tenure
abstract: An agreement reached Saturday pushes debates on U.S. participation into the administration of a new president.
snippet: An agreement reached Saturday pushes debates on U.S. participation into the administration of a new president.
lead_paragraph: NUSA DUA, Indonesia  The world’s faltering effort to cut greenhouse gas emissions got a new lease on life on Saturday, as delegates from 187 countries agreed to negotiate a new accord over the next two years  pushing the crucial debates about United States participation into the administration of a new American president.

headline: In ’08 Race, the Other Clinton Steps Up Publicly
print_headline: In ’08 Race, the Other Clinton Steps Up, for Better or Worse
abstract: Bill Clinton is not running his wife’s campaign, but he has become the most powerful force in the operation besides her.
snippet: Bill Clinton is not running his wife’s campaign, but he has become the most powerful force in the operation besides her.
lead_paragraph: DUNLAP, Iowa  When Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign advisers laid out their new political strategy in a private conference call with allies last Tuesday, Bill Clinton was not on the line. He did not need to be. The message being delivered was his.

headline: Picture of Secret Detentions Emerges in Pakistan
print_headline: Portrait of Secret Detentions Emerges in Pakistan
abstract: Nearly 100 suspected terrorists have been released in an apparent effort to avoid acknowledging secret detentions.
snippet: Nearly 100 suspected terrorists have been released in an apparent effort to avoid acknowledging secret detentions.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistan’s military and intelligence agencies, apparently trying to avoid acknowledging an elaborate secret detention system, have quietly set free nearly 100 men suspected of links to terrorism, few of whom were charged, human rights groups and lawyers here say.

headline: E.P.A. Says 17 States Can’t Set Emission Rules
print_headline: E.P.A. Says 17 States Can’t Set Greenhouse Gas Rules for Cars
abstract: The E.P.A. said the proposed California rules were made moot by the energy bill signed into law by President Bush on Wednesday.
snippet: The E.P.A. said the proposed California rules were made moot by the energy bill signed into law by President Bush on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Environmental Protection Agency on Wednesday denied California and 16 other states the right to set their own standards for carbon dioxide emissions from automobiles.

headline: Scientists Weigh Stem Cells’ Role as Cancer Cause
print_headline: Scientists Weigh Stem Cells’ Role As Cancer Cause
abstract: A debate over a hypothesis that cancers are fed by cancerous stem cells could affect the path of research.
snippet: A debate over a hypothesis that cancers are fed by cancerous stem cells could affect the path of research.
lead_paragraph: Within the next few months, researchers at three medical centers expect to start the first test in patients of one of the most promising  and contentious  ideas about the cause and treatment of cancer.

headline: Anarchists in the Aisles? Stores Provide a Stage
print_headline: Anarchists in the Aisles? Stores Provide a Stage
abstract: Shopdropping is the practice by anti-consumerist artists of leaving fake products with political messages on shelves.
snippet: Shopdropping is the practice by anti-consumerist artists of leaving fake products with political messages on shelves.
lead_paragraph: This is the season of frenetic shopping, but for a devious few people it’s also the season of spirited shopdropping.

headline: Georgia School as a Laboratory for Getting Along
print_headline: A Laboratory for Getting Along
abstract: At an unusual elementary school outside Atlanta, more than half the 380 students are refugees from some 40 countries.
snippet: At an unusual elementary school outside Atlanta, more than half the 380 students are refugees from some 40 countries.
lead_paragraph: DECATUR, Ga.  Parents at an elementary school here gathered last Thursday afternoon with a holiday mission: to prepare boxes of food for needy families fleeing some of the world’s horrific civil wars.

headline: The Ink Fades on a Profession as India Modernizes
print_headline: The Ink Fades on a Profession As India Rushes to Modernize
abstract: Cellphones made the services of the professional letter writer obsolete, but G. P. Sawant isn’t complaining.
snippet: Cellphones made the services of the professional letter writer obsolete, but G. P. Sawant isn’t complaining.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India  G. P. Sawant never charged the prostitutes for his letter-writing services.

headline: U.S. Ruling Backs Benefit Cut at 65 in Retiree Plans
print_headline: U.S. RULING BACKS BENEFIT CUT AT 65 IN RETIREE PLANS
abstract: A new regulation lets employers establish two classes of retirees, with more benefits for those under 65 and fewer, or none at all, for those older.
snippet: A new regulation lets employers establish two classes of retirees, with more benefits for those under 65 and fewer, or none at all, for those older.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said Wednesday that employers could reduce or eliminate health benefits for retirees when they turn 65 and become eligible for Medicare.

headline: Iowa Saturated by Political Ads
print_headline: Iowa Saturated by Political Ads In 11th-Hour Bid for Undecided
abstract: Campaigns are spending more on ads in Iowa, hoping to sway undecided voters.
snippet: Campaigns are spending more on ads in Iowa, hoping to sway undecided voters.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES  One week before Iowa kicks off the presidential nomination contest, the campaigns are spending three times as much money flooding the airwaves and the Internet as candidates did in 2004, hoping to sway the huge number of undecided voters after months of on-the-ground appeals.

headline: In Surprise Step, Bush Is Vetoing a Military Bill
print_headline: In Surprise Step, Bush Is Vetoing a Military Bill
abstract: President Bush said a provision that could expose Iraq to legal claims dating to Saddam Hussein’s rule was at issue.
snippet: President Bush said a provision that could expose Iraq to legal claims dating to Saddam Hussein’s rule was at issue.
lead_paragraph: CRAWFORD, Tex.  For months President Bush harangued Democrats in Congress for not moving quickly enough to support the troops and for bogging down military bills with unrelated issues.

headline: Fund Frozen, Florida Towns Feel the Pinch
print_headline: Fund Frozen, Florida Towns Feel the Pinch
abstract: Hundreds of local governments are unable to access money they deposited in a statewide investment pool.
snippet: Hundreds of local governments are unable to access money they deposited in a statewide investment pool.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  On Nov. 28, Marcia L. Dedert, finance director of this rapidly growing city, called the administrators of Florida’s state-run investment pool to ask whether it was still safe to park her city’s money there. She was hearing talk of urgent withdrawals by others worried about the pool’s investments in debt related to subprime mortgages.

headline: Mob Sets Kenya Church on Fire, Killing Dozens
print_headline: FIRE SET BY MOB AT KENYA CHURCH, KILLING DOZENS
abstract: After a disputed election, ethnic violence is threatening to engulf Kenya, formerly one of the most stable in Africa.
snippet: After a disputed election, ethnic violence is threatening to engulf Kenya, formerly one of the most stable in Africa.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya  Dozens of people seeking refuge in a church in Kenya were burned to death by a mob on Tuesday in an explosion of ethnic violence that is threatening to engulf this country, which until last week was one of the most stable in Africa.

headline: A Campaign Retools to Seek Second Clinton Comeback
print_headline: Campaigns on Each Side Retool As They Head for Next Round: Aiming for a Second Clinton Comeback
abstract: Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton have never faced a scrape quite like Tuesday’s New Hampshire primary, when their would-be dynasty will be on the line.
snippet: Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton have never faced a scrape quite like Tuesday’s New Hampshire primary, when their would-be dynasty will be on the line.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton have been in career-threatening scrapes before, but never quite like the one they face in the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday, when nothing less than their would-be dynasty will be on the line.

headline: U.S. Considers New Covert Push Within Pakistan
print_headline: U.S. CONSIDERING NEW COVERT PUSH WITHIN PAKISTAN
