snippet: A plan that could authorize more aggressive operations follows concern that Al Qaeda and the Taliban hope to destabilize the Pakistani government, officials said.
lead_paragraph: This article is by Steven Lee Myers, David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt.

headline: At Gaza’s Edge, Israelis Fear Rockets’ Whine
print_headline: In Town at Gaza’s Edge, Israelis Live in Fear of Rockets’ Whine
abstract: Sderot, Israel, a working-class town less than two miles from Gaza, has been repeatedly hit with rockets.
snippet: Sderot, Israel, a working-class town less than two miles from Gaza, has been repeatedly hit with rockets.
lead_paragraph: SDEROT, Israel  Less than two months ago, Raziel Sasson emerged from his rocket-proof closet, willing now to sleep just outside it, with the rest of his family, on mattresses circled on the living room floor. But Razi, 13, still wakes his father up three times a night, afraid to walk alone to the bathroom.

headline: Clinton’s Message, and Moment, Won the Day
print_headline: Her Message, And Moment, Won the Day
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s teary-eyed exchange with a voter and her sharpened argument on experience were among the turning points in New Hampshire.
snippet: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s teary-eyed exchange with a voter and her sharpened argument on experience were among the turning points in New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: At first, the moment seemed like a disaster: The televised images of the teary-eyed exchange Hillary Rodham Clinton had with a New Hampshire voter about the rigors of the campaign caused her advisers to express fears that it would badly undercut her message of strength and experience.

headline: Suitcase of Cash Tangles U.S. and 2 Latin Nations in Intrigue
print_headline: Suitcase of Cash Tangles U.S. And 2 Latin Nations in Intrigue
abstract: A spy mystery and diplomatic imbroglio began with the discovery of nearly $800,000 at a Buenos Aires airport.
snippet: A spy mystery and diplomatic imbroglio began with the discovery of nearly $800,000 at a Buenos Aires airport.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela  One day last August, an airport policewoman in Buenos Aires noticed something peculiar as she was monitoring a baggage scanner: the appearance of six perfect, dense rectangles inside a suitcase.

headline: Iraq Eases Curb for Former Officials of Hussein’s Party
print_headline: IRAQ EASING CURB FOR EX-OFFICIALS OF HUSSEIN PARTY
abstract: A measure to allow former officials from the Baath Party to apply for government jobs came after months of U.S. pressure.
snippet: A measure to allow former officials from the Baath Party to apply for government jobs came after months of U.S. pressure.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  The Iraqi Parliament passed a bill on Saturday that would allow some former officials from Saddam Hussein’s party to fill government positions but would impose a strict ban on others. The legislation is the first of the major so-called political benchmark measures to pass after months of American pressure for progress.

headline: Americans Cut Back Sharply on Spending
print_headline: Wallets Thick and Thin Seem to Be Closing
abstract: A pullback in spending raises the possibility that the country may be experiencing a rare decline in personal consumption.
snippet: A pullback in spending raises the possibility that the country may be experiencing a rare decline in personal consumption.
lead_paragraph: Strong evidence is emerging that consumer spending, a bulwark against recession over the last year even as energy prices surged and the housing market sputtered, has begun to slow sharply at every level of the American economy, from the working class to the wealthy.

headline: Bernanke Is Said to Support Stimulus
print_headline: Fed’s Chairman Is Said to Back Aid to Economy
abstract: The Fed chairman has said that he would back tax cuts or spending measures, so long as they are temporary.
snippet: The Fed chairman has said that he would back tax cuts or spending measures, so long as they are temporary.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, has told lawmakers that he can support tax cuts or spending measures to stimulate the economy, even if they increase the budget deficit, provided the measures are quick and temporary.

headline: Bush to Offer Stimulus Plan; Tax Rebates Expected
print_headline: Fed Chief’s Reassurance Fails to Halt Stock Plunge
abstract: The package is expected to include more than $100 billion in one-time tax rebates for individuals and an opportunity for businesses to rapidly write off their capital investments.
snippet: The package is expected to include more than $100 billion in one-time tax rebates for individuals and an opportunity for businesses to rapidly write off their capital investments.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The stock market plunged again on Thursday on bad economic news, taking little comfort from reassuring words by the chairman of the Federal Reserve or an emerging consensus about a stimulus plan that many worry could be too late.

headline: New York Measuring Teachers by Test Scores
print_headline: New York Measuring Teachers By Student Progress on Tests
abstract: Some 2,500 teachers in the city are being measured on how much their students improve on standardized tests.
snippet: Some 2,500 teachers in the city are being measured on how much their students improve on standardized tests.
lead_paragraph: New York City has embarked on an ambitious experiment, yet to be announced, in which some 2,500 teachers are being measured on how much their students improve on annual standardized tests.

headline: Feeling Misled on Home Price, Buyers Sue Agent
print_headline: Feeling Misled on Home Price, Buyers Are Suing Their Agent
abstract: Many resentful buyers may seek redress from the agents who found them a home and arranged its purchase.
snippet: Many resentful buyers may seek redress from the agents who found them a home and arranged its purchase.
lead_paragraph: CARLSBAD, Calif.  Marty Ummel feels she paid too much for her house. So do millions of other people who bought at the peak of the housing boom.

headline: French Bank Says Rogue Trader Lost $7 Billion
print_headline: French Bank Says Rogue Trader Lost $7 Billion
abstract: Société Générale said the trader made bad bets on stocks and then, in trying to cover up those losses, dug himself deeper into a hole.
snippet: Société Générale said the trader made bad bets on stocks and then, in trying to cover up those losses, dug himself deeper into a hole.
lead_paragraph: PARIS  A French bank announced Thursday that it had lost $7.2 billion, not because of complex subprime loans, but the old-fashioned way  because a 31-year-old rogue trader made bad bets on stocks and then, in trying to cover up those losses, dug himself deeper into a hole.

headline: As State Primary Nears, Pataki Is Barely Visible
print_headline: As State Primary Nears, Pataki Is Barely Visible
abstract: Once New York’s dominant Republican politician, former Gov. George E. Pataki is virtually absent from the scene.
snippet: Once New York’s dominant Republican politician, former Gov. George E. Pataki is virtually absent from the scene.
lead_paragraph: When Gov. George E. Pataki left office last January, he was the dominant Republican politician in New York. Over three terms, he had shattered fund-raising records and had racked up double-digit victory margins in an overwhelmingly Democratic state, becoming a national political figure in the process. Mr. Pataki ruled Albany for so long that even now some swatches of state bureaucracy are still run by his political appointees.

headline: Acrimony Reigns Among Republicans
print_headline: ACRIMONY REIGNS IN G.O.P. ON EVE OF FLORIDA VOTE
abstract: The candidates have traded attacks in Florida, where Tuesday’s vote could produce a clear G.O.P. front-runner.
snippet: The candidates have traded attacks in Florida, where Tuesday’s vote could produce a clear G.O.P. front-runner.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla.  The Republican contest for Florida ended in acrimony on Monday as the two leading candidates traded attacks, aggressively courting voters across the Florida peninsula in a primary battle that could produce a clear front-runner for the party’s presidential nomination before a virtual national primary next week.

headline: Financial Ties Are Cited as Issue in Spine Study
print_headline: Financial Ties Cited as Issue In Spine Study
abstract: The testing of an artificial spinal disk provides a stark example of conflicts of interest among clinical researchers.
snippet: The testing of an artificial spinal disk provides a stark example of conflicts of interest among clinical researchers.
lead_paragraph: Some of the nation’s most prominent spine surgeons hailed it as a medical breakthrough.

headline: Given Reprieve, N.F.L. Star’s Dogs Find Kindness
print_headline: Given Reprieve, N.F.L. Star’s Dogs Find Kindness

snippet: The Best Friends Animal Society sanctuary in Kanab, Utah, is a new home for 22 of Michael Vick’s former dogs.
lead_paragraph: KANAB, Utah  A quick survey of Georgia, a caramel-colored pit bull mix with cropped ears and soulful brown eyes, offers a road map to a difficult life. Her tongue juts from the left side of her mouth because her jaw, once broken, healed at an awkward angle. Her tail zigzags.

headline: Democrats Flood States With Ads as Tuesday Nears
print_headline: Democrats Flood States With Ads as Tuesday Nears
abstract: A concentrated burst of advertising is highlighting the diverging financial fortunes of the two parties.
snippet: A concentrated burst of advertising is highlighting the diverging financial fortunes of the two parties.
lead_paragraph: Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton have unleashed advertisements in nearly all the 22 states that have Democratic presidential nominating contests on Tuesday, a combined $19 million expenditure that is the most ambitious and geographically expansive television effort in a presidential primary.

headline: Time Runs Out for an Afghan Held by the U.S.
print_headline: Time Runs Out For an Afghan Held by U.S.
abstract: The fate of the first detainee to die of natural causes at Guantánamo Bay reveals the problems of military tribunals, Afghans say.
snippet: The fate of the first detainee to die of natural causes at Guantánamo Bay reveals the problems of military tribunals, Afghans say.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Abdul Razzaq Hekmati was regarded here as a war hero, famous for his resistance to the Russian occupation in the 1980s and later for a daring prison break he organized for three opponents of the Taliban government in 1999.

headline: McCain Gains Wide Support; Huckabee Wins in States in South
print_headline: Clinton Duels Obama, Takes California; McCain Surges | McCain Gains Wide Support; Huckabee Wins in States in South
abstract: Senator John McCain was successful in the delegate-rich states, while Mike Huckabee racked up victories across the South.
snippet: Senator John McCain was successful in the delegate-rich states, while Mike Huckabee racked up victories across the South.
lead_paragraph: Senator John McCain of Arizona won the most states and appeared poised to win the most delegates on Tuesday with impressive primary victories in the delegate-rich states of California, New York and Illinois. Mike Huckabee, the former Arkansas governor, revived his candidacy with victories across the South.

headline: Toll of Deadly Tornadoes in South Climbs Past 50

snippet: Authorities were searching for victims after a wide swath of storms packing tornadoes and hail swept the South.
lead_paragraph: ATKINS, Ark.  Residents in five Southern states rose Wednesday to widespread clusters of destruction caused by an unusually ferocious winter tornado system. At least 55 people were killed, and scores more were injured.

headline: Army Buried Study Faulting Iraq Planning

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Army is accustomed to protecting classified information. But when it comes to the planning for the Iraq war, even an unclassified assessment can acquire the status of a state secret.

headline: Vicious Killing Where Troubled Seek a Listener
print_headline: Vicious Killing Where Troubled Seek a Listener

lead_paragraph: It was just after 8 p.m. in a suite of mental health offices at East 79th Street and York Avenue. One doctor was seeing patients; another was working in her study.

headline: Gunman Slays 6 at N. Illinois University

snippet: Friday’s classes were canceled at Northern Illinois University after a gunman went into a lecture hall on Thursday and killed six students and himself. Fifteen other students were wounded.
lead_paragraph: DeKALB, Ill.  With minutes left in a class in ocean sciences at Northern Illinois University on Thursday afternoon, a tall skinny man dressed all in black stepped out from behind a curtain on the stage of the lecture hall, said nothing, and opened fire with a shotgun, the authorities and witnesses said.

snippet: Greeted with euphoria by ethnic Albanians, the move brings to a climax a showdown with Serbia and Russia.
lead_paragraph: PRISTINA, Kosovo  The province of Kosovo declared independence from Serbia on Sunday, sending tens of thousands of ethnic Albanians streaming through the streets to celebrate what they hoped was the end of a long and bloody struggle for national self-determination.

headline: Democrats Make Populist Appeals Before Contests

abstract: The senators are pushing their party further from the business-friendly posture championed by Bill Clinton.

lead_paragraph: WAUSAU, Wis.  Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama intensified their populist appeals on Monday, responding to widespread economic anxiety and pushing the Democratic Party further from the business-friendly posture once championed by Bill Clinton.

headline: Rescues for Homeowners in Debt Weighed
print_headline: Rescues Weighed As Homeowners Wallow in Debt

snippet: The government is considering proposals to rescue the nearly 8.8 million homeowners who are underwater.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Prodded in part by some of the nation’s biggest banks, the Bush administration and Congress are considering costly new proposals for the government to rescue hundreds of thousands of homeowners whose mortgages are higher than the value of their houses.

headline: Cheap Cocaine Floods Argentina, Devouring Lives
print_headline: Cheap Cocaine Floods a Slum In Argentina, Devouring Lives
abstract: A highly addictive, smokable cocaine residue called paco has caused a cycle of drug-induced street violence.

print_headline: Pieces of Texas Turn Primary Into a Puzzle

snippet: The rapidly mounting fight in Texas has reminded strategists yet again of the state’s unwieldy size and geographical differences.
lead_paragraph: CRAWFORD, Tex.  When Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton issued her gunslinger’s invitation to Senator Barack Obama recently, challenging him to “meet me in Texas,” the question many people here asked was, Which one?

headline: Surgeon Accused of Speeding a Death to Get Organs

abstract: A doctor faces three felony counts in a case that has sent a shudder through the field of transplant surgeons.
snippet: A doctor faces three felony counts in a case that has sent a shudder through the field of transplant surgeons.
lead_paragraph: SAN LUIS OBISPO, Calif.  On a winter night in 2006, a disabled and brain damaged man named Ruben Navarro was wheeled into an operating room at a hospital here. By most accounts, Mr. Navarro, 25, was near death, and doctors hoped that he might sustain other lives by donating his kidneys and liver.

headline: U.S.-Europe Team Beats Out Boeing on Big Contract
print_headline: U.S.-EUROPE TEAM BEATS OUT BOEING ON BIG CONTRACT
abstract: A $40 billion Air Force contract for aerial refueling tankers is now partly in the hands of a foreign company.
snippet: A $40 billion Air Force contract for aerial refueling tankers is now partly in the hands of a foreign company.

headline: Scorched-Earth Strategy Returns to Darfur
print_headline: Scorched-Earth Strategy Returns to Darfur

headline: Next Question: Can Students Be Paid to Excel?
print_headline: Next Question: Can Students Be Paid to Excel?
abstract: Many schools in New York City are experimenting with monetary incentives to promote learning.
snippet: Many schools in New York City are experimenting with monetary incentives to promote learning.
lead_paragraph: The fourth graders squirmed in their seats, waiting for their prizes. In a few minutes, they would learn how much money they had earned for their scores on recent reading and math exams. Some would receive nearly $50 for acing the standardized tests, a small fortune for many at this school, P.S. 188 on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

headline: Clinton Success Alters Delegate Race’s Dynamic
print_headline: Clinton Success Changes Dynamic In Delegate Hunt
abstract: After Tuesday’s primary victories for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, her focus is momentum; for her Democratic rival, Senator Barack Obama, it is math.
snippet: After Tuesday’s primary victories for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, her focus is momentum; for her Democratic rival, Senator Barack Obama, it is math.
lead_paragraph: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s victories in the primaries on Tuesday barely dented Senator Barack Obama’s lead in delegates, but they seemed to slow the Democratic Party establishment’s move in his direction while giving her campaign time to try to turn the race in her favor.

headline: Obama Camp Sees Fine Line in Hitting Back
print_headline: Obama Camp Sees Fine Line In Hitting Back
abstract: The resignation of an adviser to Barack Obama sparked new debates about how far he should go in responding to attacks.
snippet: The resignation of an adviser to Barack Obama sparked new debates about how far he should go in responding to attacks.
lead_paragraph: CASPER, Wyo.  Since opening his presidential bid 14 months ago, Senator Barack Obama of Illinois has answered many questions about his candidacy.

headline: Math Suggests College Frenzy Will Soon Ease
print_headline: Math Suggests College Frenzy Will Soon Ease
abstract: The number of high school graduates is projected to start declining, which could make it easier to get into college.
snippet: The number of high school graduates is projected to start declining, which could make it easier to get into college.
lead_paragraph: High school seniors nationwide are anxiously awaiting the verdicts from the colleges of their choice later this month. But though it may not be of much solace to them, in just a few years the admissions frenzy is likely to ease. It’s simply a matter of demographics.

headline: Pakistan Rivals Join to Fight Musharraf
print_headline: Musharraf Foes Reach an Accord To Cut His Power

snippet: The leaders of the two major political parties agreed that they would reinstate the judges the Pakistani president fired, which may create a challenge to his presidency.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The leaders of the two major political parties here, in an unexpectedly strong show of unity against President Pervez Musharraf, agreed Sunday that they would reinstate the judges fired by the president and would seek to strip him of crucial powers.

headline: Pentagon Cites Tapes Showing Interrogations
print_headline: Pentagon Cites Tapes Showing Interrogations
abstract: The initial findings represent the first official acknowledgment that interrogators taped some sessions with detainees.
snippet: The initial findings represent the first official acknowledgment that interrogators taped some sessions with detainees.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Defense Department is conducting an extensive review of the videotaping of interrogations at military facilities from Iraq to Guantánamo Bay, and so far it has identified nearly 50 tapes, including one that showed what a military spokesman described as the forcible gagging of a terrorism suspect.

headline: Reaching Out, Paterson Offers Different Tone
print_headline: Reaching Out, Paterson Offers Different Tone
abstract: Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson began quickly laying the groundwork for when he is formally sworn in as governor on Monday.
snippet: Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson began quickly laying the groundwork for when he is formally sworn in as governor on Monday.
lead_paragraph: With sorrow, seriousness and a dollop of humor, Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson opened his first full day as governor-in-waiting Thursday, pledging his continued commitment to Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s agenda but breaking markedly with the governor’s style.

headline: JP Morgan Pays $2 a Share for Bear Stearns
print_headline: Sale Price of $2 a Share Reflects the Depth of Problems Faced by Bear Stearns

snippet: In a shocking deal reached on Sunday to save Bear Stearns, JPMorgan Chase agreed to pay less than one-tenth the firm’s market price on Friday.
lead_paragraph: In a shocking deal reached on Sunday to save Bear Stearns, JPMorgan Chase agreed to pay a mere $2 a share to buy all of Bear  less than one-tenth the firm’s market price on Friday.

headline: Bush Backs Fed’s Actions, but Critics Quickly Find Fault
print_headline: Bush Supports Fed’s Actions, But Critics Quickly Find Fault
abstract: The White House faced accusations that it is helping a corporate giant but doing little to aid people facing foreclosure.
snippet: The White House faced accusations that it is helping a corporate giant but doing little to aid people facing foreclosure.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Bush on Monday welcomed the Federal Reserve’s sweeping intervention in the nation’s financial markets as his administration faced accusations that it had supported the bailout of a prestigious investment bank while doing little to address the hardships of Americans facing foreclosures on their homes.

headline: Slump Moves From Wall St. to Main St.
print_headline: Slump Moves From Wall St. To Main St.
abstract: The economic downturn is seeping into new parts of the country, to communities that seemed insulated only months ago.
snippet: The economic downturn is seeping into new parts of the country, to communities that seemed insulated only months ago.
lead_paragraph: In Seattle, sales at a long-established hardware store, Pacific Supply, are suddenly dipping. In Oklahoma City, couples planning their weddings are demonstrating uncustomary thrift, forgoing Dungeness crab and special linens. And in many cities, the registers at department stores like Nordstrom on the higher end and J. C. Penney in the middle are ringing less often.

headline: Jets and Giants Fans May Pay for the Right to Pay for Tickets
print_headline: Jets and Giants Fans May Pay For the Right to Pay for Tickets
abstract: For the first time, the selling of personal seat licenses, which entitle a fan to the first call on season tickets, is a real possibility in the New York area.
snippet: For the first time, the selling of personal seat licenses, which entitle a fan to the first call on season tickets, is a real possibility in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: National Football League franchises across the country have helped pay for modern stadiums since the mid-1990s by asking season-ticket holders to ante up for the right to preserve their seat locations in the teams’ new homes.

headline: Jittery Markets Make the Most of Good News
print_headline: Jittery Markets Make the Most Of Good News
abstract: Stocks surged on Monday after last-minute negotiations salvaged the rescue of Bear Stearns and housing sales snapped a long streak of declines.
snippet: Stocks surged on Monday after last-minute negotiations salvaged the rescue of Bear Stearns and housing sales snapped a long streak of declines.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street appears to be developing a case of whiplash.

headline: McCain Rejects Broad U.S. Aid on Mortgages
print_headline: Unlike Rivals, McCain Rejects Broad U.S. Aid on Mortgages
abstract: John McCain drew a sharp distinction with the Democratic presidential candidates, placing some of the blame on homeowners.
snippet: John McCain drew a sharp distinction with the Democratic presidential candidates, placing some of the blame on homeowners.
lead_paragraph: SANTA ANA, Calif.  Drawing a sharp distinction between himself and the two Democratic presidential candidates, Senator John McCain of Arizona warned Tuesday against vigorous government action to solve the deepening mortgage crisis and the market turmoil it has caused, saying that “it is not the duty of government to bail out and reward those who act irresponsibly, whether they are big banks or small borrowers.”

headline: U.S. Airstrikes Aid Iraqi Army in Basra
print_headline: U.S. Airstrikes Aid Iraqi Army In Basra Siege
abstract: Iraqi forces, which have no air support of their own, have so far failed to subdue Shiite militias in Basra and have asked the Americans and British for help.
snippet: Iraqi forces, which have no air support of their own, have so far failed to subdue Shiite militias in Basra and have asked the Americans and British for help.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  The American military conducted airstrikes Thursday and Friday to back up stalled Iraqi forces in Basra and battle Shiite militias in Baghdad as continued violence and political infighting worsened the prospects for any timely reconciliation among Iraq’s warring factions.

headline: Shiite Militias Cling to Swaths of Basra and Stage Raids
print_headline: SHIITE MILITIAS CLING TO BASRA AND STAGE RAIDS
abstract: Militias openly controlled many areas of the city as Iraqi political leaders grew increasingly critical of the stalled assault.
snippet: Militias openly controlled many areas of the city as Iraqi political leaders grew increasingly critical of the stalled assault.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Shiite militiamen in Basra openly controlled wide swaths of the city on Saturday and staged increasingly bold raids on Iraqi government forces sent five days ago to wrest control from the gunmen, witnesses said, as Iraqi political leaders grew increasingly critical of the stalled assault.

headline: Talks May End Mugabe’s Rule in Zimbabwe
print_headline: Talks May End Mugabe’s Rule In Zimbabwe
abstract: Opposition members said that negotiations were under way for President Robert G. Mugabe to step down, while state-run media reported that a runoff is likely.
snippet: Opposition members said that negotiations were under way for President Robert G. Mugabe to step down, while state-run media reported that a runoff is likely.
lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe  President Robert Mugabe’s decades-old control of Zimbabwe seemed to erode further on Tuesday, as diplomats, analysts and opposition members contended that talks were under way for the 84-year-old leader to step down after trailing in Saturday’s election.

headline: Mugabe Foes Win Majority in Zimbabwe
print_headline: Mugabe Foes Win Majority In Zimbabwe
abstract: President Robert G. Mugabe’s ruling party lost control of the nation’s Parliament. Will the presidency be next?
snippet: President Robert G. Mugabe’s ruling party lost control of the nation’s Parliament. Will the presidency be next?
lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe  President Robert G. Mugabe and his party have lost control of the nation’s Parliament, official election returns showed Wednesday, giving new impetus to the bigger question: Does that foretell a loss of the presidency itself, the job he has held tightly for the past 28 years?

headline: A Town Under Fire Becomes a Symbol for Israel
print_headline: A Town Under Fire Becomes a Symbol for Israel
abstract: Sderot, which has been pounded by Palestinian rockets, is on the front line of Israel’s battle for legitimacy and self-respect .
snippet: Sderot, which has been pounded by Palestinian rockets, is on the front line of Israel’s battle for legitimacy and self-respect .
lead_paragraph: SDEROT, Israel  This long neglected immigrant town a mile from Gaza, pounded by Palestinian rockets for the past seven years, is taking on a new identity, edging into the center of Zionist consciousness as a symbol of the nation’s unofficial motto: “Never Again.”

headline: Army Is Worried by Rising Stress of Return Tours to Iraq
print_headline: Army Is Worried By Rising Stress Of Return Tours
abstract: Army leaders are expressing increased alarm about the mental health of soldiers who would be sent on multiple deployments to Iraq under current plans.
snippet: Army leaders are expressing increased alarm about the mental health of soldiers who would be sent on multiple deployments to Iraq under current plans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Army leaders are expressing increased alarm about the mental health of soldiers who would be sent back to the front again and again under plans that call for troop numbers to be sustained at high levels in Iraq for this year and beyond.

headline: Pork Barrel Remains Hidden in U.S. Budget
print_headline: Pork Barrel, by a Softer Name, Remains Hidden in the Budget
abstract: Lawmakers can secretly direct billions of dollars to pet projects through vague requests called “soft earmarks.”
snippet: Lawmakers can secretly direct billions of dollars to pet projects through vague requests called “soft earmarks.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Sometimes on Capitol Hill, lawmakers find that it pays to ask nicely instead of just ordering the bureaucrats around.

headline: Partisan Tangle Over Trade Pact With Colombia
print_headline: Partisan Tangle Over Trade Pact With Colombia
abstract: Democrats and Republicans used trade as a surrogate for an election-year battle over security and the economy.
snippet: Democrats and Republicans used trade as a surrogate for an election-year battle over security and the economy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A drive by President Bush to win passage of a modest trade deal with Colombia erupted Wednesday into an angry partisan confrontation between the White House and House Democrats, with both sides using trade as a surrogate for an election-year battle over jobs, national security and the sinking economy.

headline: Bush Signals No Further Reduction of Troops in Iraq
print_headline: Bush Signals No Further Reduction of Troops in Iraq
abstract: President Bush said that the senior U.S. commander in Iraq could “have all the time he needs” before reducing troops further.
snippet: President Bush said that the senior U.S. commander in Iraq could “have all the time he needs” before reducing troops further.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Bush said Thursday that the senior United States commander in Iraq could “have all the time he needs” before reducing American forces there any further, but he promised shorter tours for troops and longer breaks for them at home.

headline: Housing Woes in U.S. Spread Around Globe
print_headline: Housing Woes In U.S. Spread Around Globe
abstract: From Ireland to India, housing markets that soared over the last decade are falling back to earth.
snippet: From Ireland to India, housing markets that soared over the last decade are falling back to earth.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — The collapse of the housing bubble in the United States is mutating into a global phenomenon, with real estate prices swooning from the Irish countryside and the Spanish coast to Baltic seaports and even parts of northern India.

headline: In Weak Rivets, a Possible Key to Titanic’s Doom
print_headline: Hard-Pressed Titanic Builder Skimped on Rivets, Book Says
abstract: A team of scientists has uncovered new evidence that the ship’s builder used substandard rivets and rushed the project.
snippet: A team of scientists has uncovered new evidence that the ship’s builder used substandard rivets and rushed the project.
lead_paragraph: Researchers have discovered that the builder of the Titanic struggled for years to obtain enough good rivets and riveters and ultimately settled on faulty materials that doomed the ship, which sank 96 years ago Tuesday.

headline: Benedict Meets With the Victims of Sexual Abuse
print_headline: Benedict Meets With the Victims Of Sexual Abuse
abstract: The meeting made clear that a message concerning priestly abuse was central to Pope Benedict XVI’s visit.
snippet: The meeting made clear that a message concerning priestly abuse was central to Pope Benedict XVI’s visit.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Pope Benedict XVI came face to face Thursday with a scandal that has left lasting wounds on the American church, holding an unannounced meeting with several victims of sexual abuse by priests in the Boston area.

headline: Vatican Hints at Changes in Church Laws on Abuse
print_headline: Vatican Hints at Changes In Church Law on Abuse
abstract: A top official suggested that the Roman Catholic Church is considering changes related to the statute of limitations on child sexual abuse.
snippet: A top official suggested that the Roman Catholic Church is considering changes related to the statute of limitations on child sexual abuse.
lead_paragraph: After three days in which Pope Benedict XVI has persistently addressed the scandal of child sexual abuse by priests, a top Vatican official said on Friday that the church was considering changes to the canon laws that govern how it handles such cases.

headline: Racing to Victory, and Leaving the Men and the Doubters Behind
print_headline: Racing to Victory, and Leaving the Men and the Doubters Behind
abstract: Danica Patrick became the first woman to win an Indy car race, using successful fuel strategy to capture an IndyCar Series event in Motegi, Japan.
snippet: Danica Patrick became the first woman to win an Indy car race, using successful fuel strategy to capture an IndyCar Series event in Motegi, Japan.
lead_paragraph: When a 23-year-old rookie named Danica Patrick became the first woman to lead the Indianapolis 500 three years ago, she raised the tantalizing possibility that in a male-dominated American sport, a woman might for the first time stand in victory lane.

headline: As Construction Deaths Rise, Buildings Chief Faces Scrutiny
print_headline: As Construction Deaths Rise, Buildings Chief Faces Scrutiny
abstract: Accidents and mishandled permits have raised questions about New York City’s Buildings Department commissioner.
snippet: Accidents and mishandled permits have raised questions about New York City’s Buildings Department commissioner.
lead_paragraph: The sleek glass tower at 51st Street and Second Avenue, where a crane collapse last month killed seven, rises 18 stories, nearly halfway to its promise of 43 stories, 180 luxury apartments and panoramic views of the city.

headline: Murdoch Moving to Buy Newsday for $580 Million
print_headline: Murdoch Moving To Buy Newsday For $580 Million
abstract: A tentative deal to buy his third New York newspaper would tighten Rupert Murdoch’s grip on American news media.
snippet: A tentative deal to buy his third New York newspaper would tighten Rupert Murdoch’s grip on American news media.
lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch is moving to tighten his already-imposing grip on American news media, striking a tentative deal to buy his third New York-based paper, Newsday, and getting his first chance to appoint the top editor of The Wall Street Journal, after the resignation of the editor on Tuesday.

headline: Judge Acquits Detectives in 50-Shot Killing of Bell
print_headline: Judge Acquits Detectives in 50-Shot Killing of Bell
abstract: Three detectives were found not guilty in the 2006 shooting of Sean Bell, who died on his wedding day in a hail of police bullets.
snippet: Three detectives were found not guilty in the 2006 shooting of Sean Bell, who died on his wedding day in a hail of police bullets.
lead_paragraph: A Queens judge on Friday acquitted three detectives charged in the shooting of Sean Bell, who died on his wedding day in a hail of 50 police bullets. He said that prosecutors had failed to prove their case and that wounded friends of the slain man had given testimony that he did not believe.

headline: Recession Diet Just One Way to Tighten Belt
print_headline: Recession Diet Just One Way To Tighten Belt
abstract: Americans are finding creative ways to cut costs on routine items, forcing retailers to decode the tastes of a suddenly thrifty public.
snippet: Americans are finding creative ways to cut costs on routine items, forcing retailers to decode the tastes of a suddenly thrifty public.
lead_paragraph: Stung by rising gasoline and food prices, Americans are finding creative ways to cut costs on routine items like groceries and clothing, forcing retailers, restaurants and manufacturers to decode the tastes of a suddenly thrifty public.

headline: An Angry Obama Renounces Ties to His Ex-Pastor
print_headline: An Angry Obama Renounces Ties to His Ex-Pastor
abstract: A week before two key primaries, the controversy surrounding his ex-pastor again erupted into a threat to Barack Obama’s ability to unify the Democrats.
snippet: A week before two key primaries, the controversy surrounding his ex-pastor again erupted into a threat to Barack Obama’s ability to unify the Democrats.
lead_paragraph: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C.  Senator Barack Obama broke forcefully on Tuesday with his former pastor, the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., in an effort to curtail a drama of race, values, patriotism and betrayal that has enveloped his presidential candidacy at a critical juncture.

headline: Afghans See Link to Qaeda in Plot to Shoot Karzai
print_headline: AFGHANS SEE LINK TO QAEDA IN PLOT TO SHOOT KARZAI
abstract: The Afghan intelligence chief said the attempt to kill President Hamid Karzai was the work of militants who had infiltrated his country’s security forces.
snippet: The Afghan intelligence chief said the attempt to kill President Hamid Karzai was the work of militants who had infiltrated his country’s security forces.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  The attempt to kill President Hamid Karzai on Sunday was the work of militants who had infiltrated Afghanistan’s security forces and had ties to groups linked to Al Qaeda in Pakistan’s tribal areas, the Afghan intelligence chief said Wednesday.

headline: Turkish Schools Offer Pakistan a Gentler Vision of Islam
print_headline: Turkish Schools Offer Pakistan a Gentler Islam
abstract: Turkish educators are offering an alternative approach to religious schools that could reduce extremists’ influence.
snippet: Turkish educators are offering an alternative approach to religious schools that could reduce extremists’ influence.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan  Praying in Pakistan has not been easy for Mesut Kacmaz, a Muslim teacher from Turkey.

headline: Few Details on Immigrants Who Died in Custody
print_headline: Few Details on Immigrants Who Died in U.S. Custody
abstract: Immigration detainees and their families lack basic ways to get information when things go wrong.
snippet: Immigration detainees and their families lack basic ways to get information when things go wrong.
lead_paragraph: Word spread quickly inside the windowless walls of the Elizabeth Detention Center, an immigration jail in New Jersey: A detainee had fallen, injured his head and become incoherent. Guards had put him in solitary confinement, and late that night, an ambulance had taken him away more dead than alive.

headline: Support for Clinton Wanes as Obama Sees Finish Line
print_headline: As Support Fades, Clinton Focuses on Next Contest
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton struck a publicly defiant posture, while some of her advisers acknowledged privately that they remained unsure about the future of her candidacy.
snippet: Hillary Rodham Clinton struck a publicly defiant posture, while some of her advisers acknowledged privately that they remained unsure about the future of her candidacy.
lead_paragraph: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton struck a publicly defiant posture on Wednesday about continuing her presidential bid despite waning support from Democratic officials and donors. Some of her advisers acknowledged privately that they remained unsure about the future of her candidacy.

headline: U.N. Pressures Myanmar to Allow Aid
print_headline: U.N. Pressuring Myanmar to End Barriers to Aid
abstract: Frustrated United Nations officials all but demanded that the nation end barriers to supplies and workers.
snippet: Frustrated United Nations officials all but demanded that the nation end barriers to supplies and workers.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS  With up to 1.5 million people in Myanmar now believed to be facing the threat of starvation and disease and with relief efforts still largely stymied by the country’s isolationist military rulers, frustrated United Nations officials all but demanded Thursday that the government open its doors to supplies and aid workers.

headline: Drive in Basra by Iraqi Army Makes Gains
print_headline: Drive in Basra By Iraqi Army Makes Gains
abstract: Three hundred miles south of Baghdad, Basra has been transformed by its own surge, now seven weeks old.
snippet: Three hundred miles south of Baghdad, Basra has been transformed by its own surge, now seven weeks old.
lead_paragraph: BASRA, Iraq  Three hundred miles south of Baghdad, the oil-saturated city of Basra has been transformed by its own surge, now seven weeks old.

headline: A Liberal Wit Builds Bridges to the G.O.P.
print_headline: Symbol of Left Learns to Build Bridge to G.O.P.
abstract: Barney Frank, the rumpled, cantankerous Massachusetts Democrat, has emerged as a key deal-maker in the House.
snippet: Barney Frank, the rumpled, cantankerous Massachusetts Democrat, has emerged as a key deal-maker in the House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Representative Barney Frank, the rumpled, cantankerous chairman of the Financial Services Committee, plopped down on a leather bench off the House floor last week. After two months of trying to win Republican support for his bill to help homeowners at risk of foreclosure, he had come up short.

headline: In Departure, China Invites Outside Help
print_headline: In Departure, China Invites Outside Help
abstract: China sought experts and equipment from Japan and Taiwan as President Hu Jintao visited the area affected by the earthquake.
snippet: China sought experts and equipment from Japan and Taiwan as President Hu Jintao visited the area affected by the earthquake.
lead_paragraph: MIANYANG, China  With the death toll from this week’s earthquake rising rapidly, China has departed from past diplomatic practice, seeking disaster relief experts and heavy equipment needed for rescue operations from neighbors it has long shunned as rivals or renegades.

headline: Mayoral Hopeful, an Earmark Critic, Has His Own
print_headline: Weiner Objects to Earmarks, but Has His Own
abstract: As a congressman, Anthony D. Weiner has earmarked funds to spread around — and he has been willing to do so.
snippet: As a congressman, Anthony D. Weiner has earmarked funds to spread around — and he has been willing to do so.
lead_paragraph: There is no doubt that Anthony D. Weiner wants to be mayor of New York. And there is no doubt, to that end, that he has seen an opening to wound a rival: criticizing Christine C. Quinn and the City Council he once was a member of for doling out money to favored groups in their districts.

headline: McCain Finds a Thorny Path in Ethics Effort
print_headline: McCain Finds A Thorny Path In Ethics Effort
abstract: The process of purging John McCain’s campaign of conflicts of interest has focused more attention on his advisers’ backgrounds.
snippet: The process of purging John McCain’s campaign of conflicts of interest has focused more attention on his advisers’ backgrounds.
lead_paragraph: Sorting out the lobbying entanglements of his campaign advisers is proving to be a messy business for Senator John McCain.

headline: Obama Declares Bid ‘Within Reach’ After 2 Primaries
print_headline: OBAMA DECLARES BID ‘WITHIN REACH’ AFTER 2 PRIMARIES
abstract: After a victory in Oregon and a lopsided loss in Kentucky, Barack Obama said he had enough pledged delegates to claim a nearly insurmountable edge.
snippet: After a victory in Oregon and a lopsided loss in Kentucky, Barack Obama said he had enough pledged delegates to claim a nearly insurmountable edge.
lead_paragraph: Senator Barack Obama took a big step toward becoming the Democratic presidential nominee on Tuesday, amassing enough additional delegates to claim an all but insurmountable advantage in his race against Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Teeth Gritted, Drivers Adjust to $4 Gasoline
print_headline: Teeth Gritted, Drivers Adjust To $4 Gasoline
abstract: Americans are giving up their gas guzzlers, making fewer trips to the mall and even riding public transportation.
snippet: Americans are giving up their gas guzzlers, making fewer trips to the mall and even riding public transportation.
lead_paragraph: Hating every minute of it, Americans are slowly learning to live with high gasoline prices. For a nation accustomed to cheap fuel, big vehicles and sprawling suburbs, the adjustments are wrenching.

headline: Chinese Are Left to Ask Why Schools Crumbled
print_headline: Chinese Are Left to Ask Why Schools Crumbled
abstract: A staggering number of students died as schools collapsed in the May 12 earthquake, and grieving parents are speaking out about shoddy construction.
snippet: A staggering number of students died as schools collapsed in the May 12 earthquake, and grieving parents are speaking out about shoddy construction.
lead_paragraph: This story was reported by Jim Yardley, Jake Hooker and Andrew C. Revkin, and was written by Mr. Yardley.

headline: Hint of Hope as Child Obesity Rate Hits Plateau
print_headline: Hint of Hope as Obesity Rate Among Children Hits Plateau
abstract: Childhood obesity, on the rise for more than two decades, appears to be holding steady, a new study indicates.
snippet: Childhood obesity, on the rise for more than two decades, appears to be holding steady, a new study indicates.
lead_paragraph: Childhood obesity, rising for more than two decades, appears to have hit a plateau, a potentially significant milestone in the battle against excessive weight gain among children.

headline: Racial Shift in a Progressive City Spurs Talks
print_headline: Change in a Progressive City Spurs Racial Shift, and Talks
abstract: Portland, Ore., is encouraging black and white residents to talk about gentrification and race.
snippet: Portland, Ore., is encouraging black and white residents to talk about gentrification and race.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore.  Not every neighborhood in this city is one of those Northwest destinations where passion for espresso, the environment and plenty of exercise define the cultural common ground. A few places are still described as frontiers, where pioneers move because prices are relatively reasonable, the location is convenient and, they say, they “want the diversity.”

headline: Baghdad Jews Have Become a Fearful Few
print_headline: Baghdad Jews Have Become A Fearful Few
abstract: Just over 50 years ago, Iraq’s Jews numbered more than 130,000, but only seven or eight still remain, groups say.
snippet: Just over 50 years ago, Iraq’s Jews numbered more than 130,000, but only seven or eight still remain, groups say.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  “I have no future here to stay.”

headline: Student Loans Start to Bypass 2-Year Colleges
print_headline: Student Loans Start to Bypass 2-Year Colleges
abstract: Some of the nation’s biggest banks have cut off students at community colleges and other less competitive schools.
snippet: Some of the nation’s biggest banks have cut off students at community colleges and other less competitive schools.
lead_paragraph: Some of the nation’s biggest banks have closed their doors to students at community colleges, for-profit universities and other less competitive institutions, even as they continue to extend federally backed loans to students at the nation’s top universities.

headline: A City Where Hospitals Are as Ill as the Patients
print_headline: A City Where Hospitals Are as Ill as the Patients
abstract: Since a large hospital closed last summer, thousands of people in South Los Angeles have scrambled for care.
snippet: Since a large hospital closed last summer, thousands of people in South Los Angeles have scrambled for care.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  The patients line up at 6:30 a.m. outside the tidy clinic. Two hours later, when it opens, they will sit and wait some more.

headline: 2 Leaders Ousted From Air Force in Atomic Errors
print_headline: 2 Leaders Ousted From Air Force In Atomic Errors
abstract: The decision followed an inquiry into the mishandling of nuclear weapons that found systemic problems.
snippet: The decision followed an inquiry into the mishandling of nuclear weapons that found systemic problems.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Air Force’s senior civilian official and its highest-ranking general were ousted by Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates on Thursday after an inquiry into the mishandling of nuclear weapons and components found systemic problems in the Air Force.

headline: Clinton Ends Campaign With Clear Call to Elect Obama
print_headline: Clinton Ends Bid With Clear Call To Elect Obama
abstract: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton made an emotional and unequivocal appeal for her voters to get behind Senator Barack Obama.
snippet: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton made an emotional and unequivocal appeal for her voters to get behind Senator Barack Obama.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton brought her campaign for the White House to an end on Saturday with a rousing farewell to thousands of supporters here and an emotional and unequivocal call for her voters to get behind Senator Barack Obama, the man who defeated her for the Democratic nomination.

headline: Experts See Gains Against Asian Terror Networks
print_headline: Asian Gains Seen In Terror Fight
abstract: Policing, improved intelligence and eroded public support have weakened Southeast Asian terrorist networks.
snippet: Policing, improved intelligence and eroded public support have weakened Southeast Asian terrorist networks.
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE  The deadliest terrorist networks in Southeast Asia have suffered significant setbacks in the past three years, weakened by aggressive policing, improved intelligence, enhanced military operations and an erosion of public support, government officials and counterterrorism specialists say.

headline: King Coal Country Debates a Sacrilege, Gas Heat
print_headline: King Coal Country Debates a Sacrilege, Gas Heat
abstract: Officials in the heart of Pennsylvania’s coal mining region are considering using natural gas at county facilities.
snippet: Officials in the heart of Pennsylvania’s coal mining region are considering using natural gas at county facilities.
lead_paragraph: POTTSVILLE, Pa.  Over the last 150 years, Schuylkill County has been famous for a rare hard coal called anthracite that fed the explosive growth of the East Coast during the Industrial Revolution, fostered the rise of the United Mine Workers union and powered many of the factories that supplied troops through both world wars.

headline: Deafening Howl, Then Deadly Chaos for Scouts
print_headline: Pelting Rain, Deafening Howl, Then Deadly Chaos for Scouts
abstract: Four died when a tornado hit a Boy Scout camp in Iowa, destroying the building around a troop and injuring 48.
snippet: Four died when a tornado hit a Boy Scout camp in Iowa, destroying the building around a troop and injuring 48.
lead_paragraph: BLENCOE, Iowa  Just before the tornado hit, the Boy Scouts were gathering on the porch of a shelter, playing cards and waiting out what many of them thought was just a pelting rain. In a matter of moments, a scout leader, hearing a faint tornado siren, hurried them inside, and then, as he stared out the open door and saw the twister in the distance, ordered them to dive under tables, survivors said.

headline: Lost in E-Mail, Tech Firms Face Self-Made Beast
print_headline: Lost in E-Mail, Tech Firms Face Self-Made Beast
abstract: Some of the biggest technology companies have formed a group to fight information overload.
snippet: Some of the biggest technology companies have formed a group to fight information overload.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  The onslaught of cellphone calls and e-mail and instant messages is fracturing attention spans and hurting productivity. It is a common complaint. But now the very companies that helped create the flood are trying to mop it up.

headline: Booming, China Faults U.S. Policy on the Economy
print_headline: Booming, China Faults U.S. Policy On the economy
abstract: Americans once scolded the Chinese on mismanaging their economy. But in recent weeks, the fingers have been wagging in the other direction.
snippet: Americans once scolded the Chinese on mismanaging their economy. But in recent weeks, the fingers have been wagging in the other direction.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING  Not long ago, Chinese officials sat across conference tables from American officials and got an earful.

headline: A Disabled Swimmer’s Dream, a Mother’s Fight
print_headline: A Disabled Swimmer’s Dream, a Mother’s Fight
abstract: Questions about an athlete’s eligibility for the Paralympics prompted a dedicated effort from his mother.
snippet: Questions about an athlete’s eligibility for the Paralympics prompted a dedicated effort from his mother.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO  As Kendall Bailey swims, his praying-mantis limbs flapping him forward, something about the water disguises his many maladies: cerebral palsy, mental retardation, autism and more. Only in a swimming pool do they dissolve and allow his troubled body and mind to be all but normal. He is happy, safe and possibly the fastest disabled breaststroker in the world.

headline: In China’s Medal Factory, Winners Cannot Quit
print_headline: In China’s Medal Factory, Winners Cannot Quit
abstract: Many athletes who go to special schools are unprepared to leave the sports system that has raised them, critics say.
snippet: Many athletes who go to special schools are unprepared to leave the sports system that has raised them, critics say.
lead_paragraph: FENGCHENG, China  As a reward for winning an Olympic gold medal in flatwater canoeing four years ago, Yang Wenjun  the son of peasant rice farmers  was handed the deed to a three-bedroom apartment here in a neighborhood called Sunny City.

headline: Assassins in Zimbabwe Aim at the Grass Roots
print_headline: As Zimbabwe’s Election Nears, Assassins Aim at the Grass Roots
abstract: At least 85 people have been killed in a campaign against the opposition in a presidential runoff, civic groups said.
snippet: At least 85 people have been killed in a campaign against the opposition in a presidential runoff, civic groups said.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG  Tonderai Ndira was a shrewd choice for assassination: young, courageous and admired. Kill him and fear would pulse through a thousand spines. He was an up-and-comer in Zimbabwe’s opposition party, a charismatic figure with a strong following in the Harare slums where he lived.

headline: Top Engineers Shun Military; Concern Grows
print_headline: Top Engineers Shun Military; Concern Grows
abstract: As engineers seek higher pay at civilian companies, the Pentagon is losing the people it needs to manage projects.
snippet: As engineers seek higher pay at civilian companies, the Pentagon is losing the people it needs to manage projects.
lead_paragraph: When Paul G. Kaminski completed his graduate work in 1971 with degrees from M.I.T. and Stanford, he started building advanced airplanes for the Air Force. By the time he stopped several decades later, he had played a pivotal role in producing a flock of new weapons, including radar-evading stealth aircraft.

headline: Justices Bar Death Penalty for the Rape of a Child
print_headline: Justices Bar Death Penalty For the Rape of a Child
abstract: The death penalty is unconstitutional as a punishment for the rape of a child, a divided Supreme Court ruled.
snippet: The death penalty is unconstitutional as a punishment for the rape of a child, a divided Supreme Court ruled.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The death penalty is unconstitutional as a punishment for the rape of a child, a sharply divided Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday.

headline: Zimbabwe Faces Wider Sanctions Under Bush Plan
print_headline: Zimbabwe Faces Wider Sanctions Under Bush Plan
abstract: After Zimbabwe’s widely denounced presidential runoff, President Bush announced new steps aimed at what he called an “illegitimate government.”
snippet: After Zimbabwe’s widely denounced presidential runoff, President Bush announced new steps aimed at what he called an “illegitimate government.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Bush called Saturday for an international arms embargo against Zimbabwe in the wake of last week’s “sham election,” and announced that the United States is drafting new economic sanctions that, for the first time, would take aim at the entire government of President Robert Mugabe.

headline: U.S. Advised Iraqi Ministry on Oil Deals
print_headline: U.S. Advised Iraqi Ministry On Oil Deals
abstract: The disclosure, on the eve of the contracts’ announcement, is the first confirmation of direct American involvement in deals to open Iraq’s oil to commercial development.
snippet: The disclosure, on the eve of the contracts’ announcement, is the first confirmation of direct American involvement in deals to open Iraq’s oil to commercial development.
lead_paragraph: A group of American advisers led by a small State Department team played an integral part in drawing up contracts between the Iraqi government and five major Western oil companies to develop some of the largest fields in Iraq, American officials say.

headline: The ’60s Begin to Fade as Liberal Professors Retire
print_headline: On Campus, the ’60s Begin to Fade as Liberal Professors Retire
abstract: Hired during an expansion in higher education, baby boomers are being replaced by a new generation.
snippet: Hired during an expansion in higher education, baby boomers are being replaced by a new generation.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis.  When Michael Olneck was standing, arms linked with other protesters, singing “We Shall Not Be Moved” in front of Columbia University’s library in 1968, Sara Goldrick-Rab had not yet been born.

headline: Obama Fuels Pullout Debate With Remarks
print_headline: Obama Fuels Pullout Debate With Remarks
abstract: Change in Iraq has posed a challenge for Barack Obama, who said he might “refine” his policies but later held a news conference to clarify his statement.
snippet: Change in Iraq has posed a challenge for Barack Obama, who said he might “refine” his policies but later held a news conference to clarify his statement.
lead_paragraph: Senator Barack Obama said Thursday that he might “refine” his policies for Iraq after meeting with military commanders there later this summer. But hours later he held a second news conference to emphasize his commitment to the withdrawal of all combat troops from Iraq within 16 months of taking office.

headline: Doctors Press Senate to Undo Medicare Cuts
print_headline: DOCTORS PRESS SENATE TO UNDO MEDICARE CUTS
abstract: Ads by the American Medical Association blame Senate Republicans for a 10.6 percent cut in payments to doctors who care for older Americans.
snippet: Ads by the American Medical Association blame Senate Republicans for a 10.6 percent cut in payments to doctors who care for older Americans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Congress returns to work this week with Medicare high on the agenda and Senate Republicans under pressure after a barrage of radio and television advertisements blamed them for a 10.6 percent cut in payments to doctors who care for millions of older Americans.

headline: Forget Gossip, Girl; the Buzz Is About the Clothes
print_headline: Forget Gossip, Girl, the Buzz Is About the Clothes
abstract: “Gossip Girl” is more than a series about students at elite private schools. It also presents a cavalcade of fashion.
snippet: “Gossip Girl” is more than a series about students at elite private schools. It also presents a cavalcade of fashion.
lead_paragraph: Since its debut last fall, “Gossip Girl” has always been more than a television series about its overt subject, the social machinations of Manhattan private-school students.

headline: U.S. Weighs Takeover of Two Mortgage Giants
print_headline: U.S. Weighs Takeover Plan For Two Mortgage Giants
abstract: Under the plan, shares of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac would be worth little or nothing, and any losses on mortgages they own or guarantee would be paid by taxpayers.
snippet: Under the plan, shares of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac would be worth little or nothing, and any losses on mortgages they own or guarantee would be paid by taxpayers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Alarmed by the growing financial stress at the nation’s two largest mortgage finance companies, senior Bush administration officials are considering a plan to have the government take over one or both of the companies and place them in a conservatorship if their problems worsen, people briefed about the plan said on Thursday.

headline: 2 Vetoes Quash U.N. Sanctions on Zimbabwe
print_headline: 2 Vetoes Quash U.N. Sanctions On Zimbabwe
abstract: An American-led effort to impose sanctions against Zimbabwe failed in the Security Council, with Russia and China exercising a rare double veto.
snippet: An American-led effort to impose sanctions against Zimbabwe failed in the Security Council, with Russia and China exercising a rare double veto.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS  An American-led effort to impose sanctions against Zimbabwe failed in the Security Council on Friday, with Russia and China exercising a rare double veto to quash a resolution that they said represented excessive interference in the country’s domestic matters.

headline: Want Obama in a Punch Line? First, Find a Joke
print_headline: Want Obama in a Punch Line? First, Find a Joke
abstract: Satirizing Barack Obama has not been easy for The New Yorker magazine or the phalanx of late-night TV hosts.
snippet: Satirizing Barack Obama has not been easy for The New Yorker magazine or the phalanx of late-night TV hosts.
lead_paragraph: What’s so funny about Barack Obama? Apparently not very much, at least not yet.

headline: Prisoner Deal Reopens an Israeli Wound
print_headline: Prisoner Deal Reopens an Israeli Wound
abstract: The prospect of exchanging one of the country’s most despised prisoners for corpses has raised hackles.
snippet: The prospect of exchanging one of the country’s most despised prisoners for corpses has raised hackles.
lead_paragraph: NAHARIYA, Israel — Israel is a tale of family tragedies lived out within small distances.

headline: In Hamptons, Slump Means Less Glitz Per Gala
print_headline: In Hamptons, Slump Means Less Glitz Per Gala
abstract: Along the East End of Long Island, fund-raising is down at benefits, and charities are worrying about their futures.
snippet: Along the East End of Long Island, fund-raising is down at benefits, and charities are worrying about their futures.
lead_paragraph: BRIDGEHAMPTON, N.Y.  Trustees of the Children’s Museum of the East End rejected a dinner dance at a rented farm in favor of a cocktail party on the museum grounds here, replaced a five-piece rock ‘n’ roll cover band with a teenage jazz combo and slashed ticket prices to $150 from $450, but still only drew about 150 guests, half the number that turned out for the benefit last year.

headline: Obama’s Visit Renews Focus on Afghanistan
print_headline: Obama’s Visit Renews Focus On Afghanistan
abstract: Barack Obama stopped on a high-profile foreign trip in a country that is increasingly the focus of his clash with John McCain.
snippet: Barack Obama stopped on a high-profile foreign trip in a country that is increasingly the focus of his clash with John McCain.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Senator Barack Obama arrived in Afghanistan on Saturday, on a high-profile foreign trip in a country that is increasingly the focus of his clash with Senator John McCain over whether the war in Iraq has been a distraction in hunting down terrorists.

headline: Bosnian Serb Under Arrest in War Crimes
print_headline: BOSNIAN SERB UNDER ARREST IN WAR CRIMES
abstract: The arrest of Radovan Karadzic, one of the most wanted war criminals for the massacre of nearly 8,000 Muslim men and boys, ended a 13-year hunt.
snippet: The arrest of Radovan Karadzic, one of the most wanted war criminals for the massacre of nearly 8,000 Muslim men and boys, ended a 13-year hunt.
lead_paragraph: PARIS  Radovan Karadzic, one of the world’s most wanted war criminals for his part in the massacre of nearly 8,000 Muslim men and boys in Srebrenica in 1995, was arrested Monday in a raid in Serbia that ended a 13-year hunt.

headline: Health Plan From Obama Spurs Debate
print_headline: Health Plan From Obama Spurs Debate
abstract: Whether Barack Obama can deliver on his pledge to reduce premiums is a matter of dispute among analysts.
snippet: Whether Barack Obama can deliver on his pledge to reduce premiums is a matter of dispute among analysts.
lead_paragraph: It is one of the most audacious promises in a campaign that has been thick with them.

headline: Plan Would Use Antiterror Aid on Pakistani Jets
print_headline: PLAN WOULD USE ANTITERROR AID ON PAKISTANI JETS
abstract: The U.S. plans to shift nearly $230 million to upgrading planes that critics say are not used to fight terrorism.
snippet: The U.S. plans to shift nearly $230 million to upgrading planes that critics say are not used to fight terrorism.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration plans to shift nearly $230 million in aid to Pakistan from counterterrorism programs to upgrading that country’s aging F-16 attack planes, which Pakistan prizes more for their contribution to its military rivalry with India than for fighting insurgents along its Afghan border.

headline: California Bars Restaurant Use of Trans Fats
print_headline: CALIFORNIA BARS RESTAURANT USE OF TRANS FATS
abstract: Under a new law, the fats long linked to health problems must be excised from restaurants and retail baked goods.
snippet: Under a new law, the fats long linked to health problems must be excised from restaurants and retail baked goods.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  California, a national trendsetter in all matters edible, became the first state to ban trans fats in restaurants when Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger signed a bill Friday to phase out their use.

headline: A Shiite Militia in Baghdad Sees Its Power Wane
print_headline: A SHIITE MILITIA IN BAGHDAD SEES ITS POWER WANE
abstract: The Mahdi Army has been profoundly weakened in a number of neighborhoods, in an important, if tentative, milestone for stability in Iraq.
snippet: The Mahdi Army has been profoundly weakened in a number of neighborhoods, in an important, if tentative, milestone for stability in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  The militia that was once the biggest defender of poor Shiites in Iraq, the Mahdi Army, has been profoundly weakened in a number of neighborhoods across Baghdad, in an important, if tentative, milestone for stability in Iraq.

headline: Worried Banks Sharply Reduce Business Loans
print_headline: WORRIED BANKS SHARPLY REDUCE BUSINESS LOANS
abstract: Struggling to recover from multibillion-dollar losses, banks are curtailing loans even to healthy businesses.
snippet: Struggling to recover from multibillion-dollar losses, banks are curtailing loans even to healthy businesses.
lead_paragraph: Banks struggling to recover from multibillion-dollar losses on real estate are curtailing loans to American businesses, depriving even healthy companies of money for expansion and hiring.

headline: Badge of Honor for the New Fighter: Mangled Ear
print_headline: Mangled Ear a Badge of Honor For the New Breed of Fighter
abstract: To herald its full arrival as a major sport, mixed martial arts has claimed a signature injury: cauliflower ear.
snippet: To herald its full arrival as a major sport, mixed martial arts has claimed a signature injury: cauliflower ear.
lead_paragraph: Is your son into mixed martial arts? Check his ears.

headline: In Strangers, Centenarian Finds Literary Lifeline
print_headline: In Strangers, Centenarian Finds Literary Lifeline
abstract: A cadre of devoted friends read to Elizabeth Goodyear, who is 101, blind and confined to her Manhattan apartment.
snippet: A cadre of devoted friends read to Elizabeth Goodyear, who is 101, blind and confined to her Manhattan apartment.
lead_paragraph: Stephanie Sandleben, a yoga instructor with tattoos on each shoulder, just finished Chapter 19 of Tina Brown’s biography of Diana, Princess of Wales. Sara Nolan, a 28-year-old graduate student, is 30 pages into a Rumer Godden novel. Mark Kalinowsky, 48 and a real estate broker, has long since stopped reading; he just comes to chat.

headline: Ragtag Taliban Show Tenacity in Afghanistan
print_headline: Ragtag Taliban Show Tenacity In Afghanistan
abstract: The mounting toll inflicted by insurgents has refocused the attention of America’s military commanders.
snippet: The mounting toll inflicted by insurgents has refocused the attention of America’s military commanders.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Six years after being driven from power, the Taliban are demonstrating a resilience and a ferocity that are raising alarm here, in Washington and in other NATO capitals, and engendering a fresh round of soul-searching over how a relatively ragtag insurgency has managed to keep the world’s most powerful armies at bay.

headline: Big Donors, Too, Have Seats at Obama Fund-Raising Table
print_headline: Big Donors, Too, Have Seats At Obama Fund-Raising Table
abstract: Barack Obama cites his small donations, but a third of his record-setting haul has come from gifts of $1,000 or more.
snippet: Barack Obama cites his small donations, but a third of his record-setting haul has come from gifts of $1,000 or more.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to cast himself as independent of the influence of money on politics, Senator Barack Obama often highlights the campaign contributions of $200 or less that have amounted to fully half of the $340 million he has collected so far.

headline: China’s Leaders Try to Impress and Reassure World
print_headline:
Games Open in a New China,
Dazzling an Age of New Media
abstract: The Olympic opening ceremonies gave the Communist Party an unfiltered chance to reach a global audience.
snippet: The Olympic opening ceremonies gave the Communist Party an unfiltered chance to reach a global audience.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING  An ecstatic China finally got its Olympic moment on Friday night. And if the astonishing opening ceremonies of the 2008 Olympic Games lavished grand tribute on Chinese civilization and sought to stir an ancient nation’s pride, there was also a message for an uncertain outside world: Do not worry. We mean no harm.

headline: In Loose Style, McCain Leads a Camp Divided
print_headline: Embracing a Free-Form Style, McCain Leads a Camp Divided
abstract: John McCain has been the overseer of a kingdom with unclear lines of command that keeps aides on edge.
snippet: John McCain has been the overseer of a kingdom with unclear lines of command that keeps aides on edge.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain is so quick to pick up his gold-colored cellphone to solicit advice  from senators, campaign consultants, even the stray former deputy press secretary  that aides, concerned about his tendency to adopt the last opinion he has heard, have tried to cut back on the time he has to make calls.

headline: Before the Gunfire, Cyberattacks
print_headline: Before the Gunfire, Cyberattacks
abstract: Weeks before physical bombs fell on Georgia, a security researcher was watching an attack against the country in cyberspace.
snippet: Weeks before physical bombs fell on Georgia, a security researcher was watching an attack against the country in cyberspace.
lead_paragraph: Weeks before bombs started falling on Georgia, a security researcher in suburban Massachusetts was watching an attack against the country in cyberspace.

headline: Bush, Sending Aid, Demands That Moscow Withdraw
print_headline: BUSH, SENDING AID, DEMANDS MOSCOW WITHDRAW FORCES
abstract: President Bush made his strongest warning to Russia yet over the conflict in Georgia as he sent American troops to oversee a humanitarian mission.
snippet: President Bush made his strongest warning to Russia yet over the conflict in Georgia as he sent American troops to oversee a humanitarian mission.
lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Steven Lee Myers, Sabrina Tavernise and Ellen Barry and written by Mr. Myers.

headline: Rice, in Georgia, Calls on Russia to Pull Out Now
print_headline: RICE, IN GEORGIA, CALLS ON RUSSIA TO PULL OUT NOW
abstract: As the secretary of state tried to fix a loophole that Russia could use to justify its advance, Russian armor moved within 25 miles of Georgia’s capital, Tbilisi.
snippet: As the secretary of state tried to fix a loophole that Russia could use to justify its advance, Russian armor moved within 25 miles of Georgia’s capital, Tbilisi.
lead_paragraph: TBILISI, Georgia  The United States pressed on Friday for the immediate withdrawal of Russian forces in Georgia, as Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice came here, not far from the front lines, to win the Georgian president’s approval for a redefined cease-fire. She pushed to close a loophole that Russia could use to justify its advance deep into Georgia.

headline: Methadone Rises as a Painkiller With Big Risks
print_headline: Methadone Rises as a Painkiller With Big Risks
abstract: Once used mainly in addiction treatment, the drug is now more widely prescribed and is a growing cause of deaths.
snippet: Once used mainly in addiction treatment, the drug is now more widely prescribed and is a growing cause of deaths.
lead_paragraph: Suffering from excruciating spinal deterioration, Robby Garvin, 24, of South Carolina, tried many painkillers before his doctor prescribed methadone in June 2006, just before Mr. Garvin and his friend Joey Sutton set off for a weekend at an amusement park.

headline: Pledging to Leave Georgia, Russia Tightens Its Grip
print_headline: Russia, Pledging To Leave Georgia, Tightens Its Grip
abstract: American officials said the Russian military has been moving launchers for short-range ballistic missiles into South Ossetia.
snippet: American officials said the Russian military has been moving launchers for short-range ballistic missiles into South Ossetia.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even as Russia pledged to begin withdrawing its forces from neighboring Georgia on Monday, American officials said the Russian military had been moving launchers for short-range ballistic missiles into South Ossetia, a step that appeared intended to tighten its hold on the breakaway territory.

headline: Too Old and Frail to Re-educate? Not in China
print_headline: Too Old and Frail to Re-educate? Not in China
abstract: Two elderly women were sentenced to a year of labor after seeking to demonstrate in an official Olympic protest area.

lead_paragraph: BEIJING  In the annals of people who have struggled against Communist Party rule, Wu Dianyuan and Wang Xiuying are unlikely to merit even a footnote.

headline: 64 in Pakistan Die in Bombing at Arms Plant
print_headline: 64 in Pakistan Die in Bombing At Arms Plant
abstract: The attack was the worst by the Taliban since they began hitting government sites with suicide bombers more than 18 months ago.
snippet: The attack was the worst by the Taliban since they began hitting government sites with suicide bombers more than 18 months ago.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Two suicide bombers killed at least 64 people outside Pakistan’s biggest weapons factory complex on Thursday, in the deadliest attack by the Taliban since they began hitting Pakistani government sites with suicide bombers more than 18 months ago.

headline: A Teacher on the Front Line as Faith and Science Clash
print_headline: A Teacher on the Front Line As Faith and Science Clash

snippet: David Campbell is bringing Florida’s mandate to teach evolution to many students raised to take the biblical creation story as fact.
lead_paragraph: ORANGE PARK, Fla.  David Campbell switched on the overhead projector and wrote “Evolution” in the rectangle of light on the screen.

headline: War Veterans’ Concussions Are Often Overlooked
print_headline: Home From War, Veterans Say Head Injuries Go Unrecognized
abstract: The complications from concussions, a signature injury of the Iraq war, often are not recognized in singular ways.
snippet: The complications from concussions, a signature injury of the Iraq war, often are not recognized in singular ways.
lead_paragraph: Former Staff Sgt. Kevin Owsley is not quite sure what rattled his brain in 2004: the roadside bomb that exploded about a yard from his Humvee or the rocket-propelled grenade that flung him across a road as he walked to a Porta Potti on base six weeks later.

headline: For a New Political Age, a Self-Made Man
print_headline: For a New Political Age, a Self-Made Man

snippet: Even before he entered public life, Barack Obama began honing his political, mental and emotional skills.

headline: In Texas School, Teachers Carry Books and Guns
