snippet: A school board in north-central Texas has drawn attention by letting some teachers carry concealed weapons.
lead_paragraph: HARROLD, Tex. — Students in this tiny town of grain silos and ranch-style houses spent much of the first couple of days in school this week trying to guess which of their teachers were carrying pistols under their clothes.

headline: Alaskan Is McCain’s Choice; First Woman on G.O.P. Ticket
print_headline:
ALASKAN IS McCAIN’S CHOICE;
FIRST WOMAN ON G.O.P. TICKET
abstract: In choosing Gov. Sarah Palin, John McCain reached far outside the Beltway and selected the Republicans’ first female vice presidential candidate.
snippet: In choosing Gov. Sarah Palin, John McCain reached far outside the Beltway and selected the Republicans’ first female vice presidential candidate.
lead_paragraph: DAYTON, Ohio  Senator John McCain astonished the political world on Friday by naming Sarah Palin, a little-known governor of Alaska and self-described “hockey mom” with almost no foreign policy experience, as his running mate on the Republican presidential ticket.

headline: 2 Million Flee Storm; G.O.P. Cuts Back
print_headline: 2 Million Flee Hurricane's Path; G.O.P. Cuts Convention Events | A HISTORIC EXODUS
abstract: People from Texas to Alabama left ahead of Hurricane Gustav, fearing a storm that could rival Hurricane Katrina in its destructive power.
snippet: People from Texas to Alabama left ahead of Hurricane Gustav, fearing a storm that could rival Hurricane Katrina in its destructive power.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS  Nearly two million people from Texas to Alabama fled the Gulf Coast on Sunday ahead of Hurricane Gustav, anticipating a storm that could rival Hurricane Katrina in its destructive power.

headline: U.S. Hands Off Pacified Anbar, Once Heart of Iraq Insurgency
print_headline: U.S. Hands Off Pacified Anbar, Once Heart of Iraq Insurgency
abstract: The handover of the Iraqi province, once a stronghold of the Sunni insurgency, marked a long-delayed milestone.
snippet: The handover of the Iraqi province, once a stronghold of the Sunni insurgency, marked a long-delayed milestone.
lead_paragraph: RAMADI, Iraq — Two years ago, Anbar Province was the most lethal place for the Americans in Iraq, with a marine or a soldier dying here nearly every day. The provincial capital, Ramadi, was a moonscape of rubble and ruins. Islamic extremists controlled large pieces of territory, with some so ferocious in their personal views that they did not even allow the sale of bread.

headline: A New Twist in the Debate on Mothers
print_headline: A New Twist In the Debate Over Mothers

lead_paragraph: When Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska was introduced as a vice-presidential pick, she was presented as a magnet for female voters, the epitome of everymom appeal.

headline: Paralympic Athletes Add Equality to Their Goals
print_headline: As Paralympics Begin, U.S. Athletes Add Equality to Their Goals
abstract: Many Paralympians criticize the U.S. Olympic program for giving them fewer benefits than Olympians receive.
snippet: Many Paralympians criticize the U.S. Olympic program for giving them fewer benefits than Olympians receive.
lead_paragraph: AURORA, Ill.  When he rolls to the starting line for the 1,500-meter wheelchair race at the Paralympics, the Olympics for disabled athletes that begin Saturday in Beijing, Tony Iniguez will wear his Team USA uniform with pride. He will compete for the United States’s Olympic program. He is also suing it for discrimination.

headline: Mortgage Giant Overstated the Size of Its Capital Base
print_headline: MORTGAGE GIANT OVERSTATED SIZE OF CAPITAL BASE
abstract: Advisers poring over the books of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac concluded that Freddie’s accounting methods had overstated its cushion, officials said.
snippet: Advisers poring over the books of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac concluded that Freddie’s accounting methods had overstated its cushion, officials said.
lead_paragraph: The government’s planned takeover of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, expected to be announced as early as this weekend, came together hurriedly after advisers poring over the companies’ books for the Treasury Department concluded that Freddie’s accounting methods had overstated its capital cushion, according to regulatory officials briefed on the matter.

headline: Maimed on 9/11, Trying to Be Whole Again
print_headline: Maimed on 9/11, and Trying to Be Whole Again
abstract: For those who were injured on Sept. 11, 2001, but survived, the struggle to rebuild their lives goes on.
snippet: For those who were injured on Sept. 11, 2001, but survived, the struggle to rebuild their lives goes on.
lead_paragraph: Lauren Manning’s handshake is strong, almost bionic. You might think it was a byproduct of decades of playing tennis and golf. But her grip has been painfully relearned, and bolstered with more titanium pins than she cares to count.

headline: Rangel Tries to Explain Back Taxes on Villa
print_headline: Rangel Cites Language Barrier on Unpaid Taxes
abstract: Representative Charles B. Rangel said “cultural and language barriers” kept him from understanding the finances of his house in the Dominican Republic.
snippet: Representative Charles B. Rangel said “cultural and language barriers” kept him from understanding the finances of his house in the Dominican Republic.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Charles B. Rangel said on Wednesday that “cultural and language barriers” had hindered him from understanding the finances of his Dominican Republic beach house, and vowed to repay several thousand dollars in federal taxes he owes after failing to report $75,000 in rental income from the villa.

headline: With White House Push, U.S. Arms Sales Jump
print_headline: With Push From White House, U.S. Arms Sales Rise Sharply
abstract: Sales of weapons to foreign governments have risen to more than $32 billion, up from $12 billion in 2005.
snippet: Sales of weapons to foreign governments have risen to more than $32 billion, up from $12 billion in 2005.

headline: After Surviving Storm, Fleeing a Fetid, Devastated Galveston
print_headline: After Surviving Storm, Fleeing A Fetid, Devastated Galveston
abstract: For thousands of people stuck on Galveston Island, the aftermath of Hurricane Ike is proving to be worse than the storm.
snippet: For thousands of people stuck on Galveston Island, the aftermath of Hurricane Ike is proving to be worse than the storm.
lead_paragraph: GALVESTON, Tex.  For thousands of people stuck on an increasingly fetid Galveston Island, the aftermath of Hurricane Ike is proving to be far worse than the storm itself.

headline: McCain Seen as Less Likely to Bring Change, Poll Finds
print_headline: McCain Seen as Less Likely To Bring Change, Poll Finds
abstract: Senator John McCain is widely viewed as a “typical Republican” who would continue or expand President Bush’s policies.
snippet: Senator John McCain is widely viewed as a “typical Republican” who would continue or expand President Bush’s policies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Despite an intense effort to distance himself from the way his party has done business in Washington, Senator John McCain is seen by voters as far less likely to bring change to Washington than Senator Barack Obama. He is widely viewed as a “typical Republican” who would continue or expand President Bush’s policies, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Drug Label, Maimed Patient and Crucial Test for Justices
print_headline: Drug Label, Maimed Patient And Crucial Test for Justices
abstract: At issue is whether plaintiffs have the right to sue when the products that hurt them had met federal standards.
snippet: At issue is whether plaintiffs have the right to sue when the products that hurt them had met federal standards.
lead_paragraph: MARSHFIELD, Vt.  When Diana Levine starts talking about her rock ’n’ roll days, she plays a little air guitar, mimicking the way she used to handle her electric bass in bands like the Re-Bops and Duke and the Detours. But Ms. Levine is missing much of her right arm, which was amputated below the elbow after a medical disaster.

headline: A Disability Epidemic Among a Railroad’s Retirees

lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Walt Bogdanich, Andrew W. Lehren, Robert A. McDonald and Nicholas Phillips and written by Mr. Bogdanich.

headline: Friction Infiltrates Sunni Patrols on Safer Iraqi Streets
print_headline: On Safer Streets in Baghdad, Friction Infiltrates Sunni Patrols
abstract: The Sunni-dominated citizen patrols paid by the Americans to fight the insurgency have become increasingly unpredictable.
snippet: The Sunni-dominated citizen patrols paid by the Americans to fight the insurgency have become increasingly unpredictable.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  In Adhamiya, a neighborhood that only a year ago was among the most dangerous in Baghdad, the violence last week seemed almost negligible. A shootout near a checkpoint left two people dead on Sunday. Another man was killed on Monday by a small bomb placed under a car.

headline: Government Seizes WaMu and Sells Some Assets
print_headline: In Largest Bank Failure, U.S. Seizes, Then Sells
abstract: Washington Mutual was seized by federal regulators in what is the largest bank failure in American history.
snippet: Washington Mutual was seized by federal regulators in what is the largest bank failure in American history.
lead_paragraph: Washington Mutual, the giant lender that came to symbolize the excesses of the mortgage boom, was seized by federal regulators on Thursday night, in what is by far the largest bank failure in American history.

headline: S.E.C. Concedes Oversight Flaws Fueled Collapse
print_headline: S.E.C. CONCEDES OVERSIGHT FLAWS FUELED COLLAPSE

snippet: The commission’s chairman, a deregulation proponent, ended a voluntary supervision program for Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, a longtime proponent of deregulation, acknowledged on Friday that failures in a voluntary supervision program for Wall Street’s largest investment banks had contributed to the global financial crisis, and he abruptly shut the program down.

headline: Obama and ’60s Bomber: A Look Into Crossed Paths
print_headline:
Obama and ’60s Bomber:
A Look Into Crossed Paths
abstract: Records of a school reform project suggest Barack Obama has played down contact with Bill Ayers, a founder of the Weathermen, but they do not seem to have been close.
snippet: Records of a school reform project suggest Barack Obama has played down contact with Bill Ayers, a founder of the Weathermen, but they do not seem to have been close.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  At a tumultuous meeting of anti-Vietnam War militants at the Chicago Coliseum in 1969, Bill Ayers helped found the radical Weathermen, launching a campaign of bombings that would target the Pentagon and United States Capitol.

headline: Economic Unrest Shifts Electoral Battlegrounds
print_headline: Economic Unrest Is Shifting Electoral Battlegrounds
abstract: Barack Obama is gaining force, while John McCain is scaling back his efforts to capture Democratic states.
snippet: Barack Obama is gaining force, while John McCain is scaling back his efforts to capture Democratic states.
lead_paragraph: The turmoil on Wall Street and the weakening economy are changing the contours of the presidential campaign map, giving new force to Senator Barack Obama’s ambitious strategy to make incursions into Republican territory, while leading Senator John McCain to scale back his efforts to capture Democratic states.

headline: U.S. Markets Plunge Despite Hint of Rate Cut
print_headline: STOCKS FALL MORE DESPITE FED’S HINT IT WILL CUT RATES
abstract: Wall Street extended its heavy losses on Tuesday despite reassurances from the Fed chairman that the central bank was prepared to lower interest rates.
snippet: Wall Street extended its heavy losses on Tuesday despite reassurances from the Fed chairman that the central bank was prepared to lower interest rates.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The promise of lower interest rates and new federal efforts to stem the financial crisis failed to dispel the fear gripping Wall Street on Tuesday.

headline: U.S. May Take Ownership Stake in Banks
print_headline: U.S. MAY TAKE OWNERSHIP STAKE IN BANKS TO EASE CREDIT CRISIS
abstract: Treasury officials say the just-passed $700 billion bailout bill gives them the authority to inject cash into banks that request it.
snippet: Treasury officials say the just-passed $700 billion bailout bill gives them the authority to inject cash into banks that request it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Having tried without success to unlock frozen credit markets, the Treasury Department is considering taking ownership stakes in many United States banks to try to restore confidence in the financial system, according to government officials.

headline: Concern in G.O.P. After Rough Week for McCain
print_headline: Republicans Voicing Concern After Rough Week for McCain
abstract: Republicans said that they were worried John McCain was heading for defeat without a clear message.
snippet: Republicans said that they were worried John McCain was heading for defeat without a clear message.
lead_paragraph: After a turbulent week that included disclosures about Gov. Sarah Palin and signs that Senator John McCain was struggling to strike the right tone for his campaign, Republican leaders said Saturday that they were worried Mr. McCain was heading for defeat unless he brought stability to his presidential candidacy and settled on a clear message to counter Senator Barack Obama.

headline: Morgan Agrees to Revise Terms of Mitsubishi Deal
print_headline: MORGAN IS BACKED
abstract: The Japanese bank demanded better terms after Morgan Stanley’s stock lost about 59 percent of its value.
snippet: The Japanese bank demanded better terms after Morgan Stanley’s stock lost about 59 percent of its value.
lead_paragraph: The embattled investment bank Morgan Stanley announced Monday morning that it had closed its deal to sell a 21 percent stake to a large Japanese bank, securing a $9 billion lifeline.

headline: Drama Behind a $250 Billion Banking Deal
print_headline: Drama Behind a Banking Deal
abstract: The Treasury secretary gave little choice to nine major banks but to sell shares to the government.
snippet: The Treasury secretary gave little choice to nine major banks but to sell shares to the government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chief executives of the nine largest banks in the United States trooped into a gilded conference room at the Treasury Department at 3 p.m. Monday. To their astonishment, they were each handed a one-page document that said they agreed to sell shares to the government, then Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. said they must sign it before they left.

headline: Candidates Clash Over Character and Policy
print_headline:
Lively Exchanges
on Policy and
Character
abstract: Senator John McCain raised questions about Senator Barack Obama in their most combative encounter.
snippet: Senator John McCain raised questions about Senator Barack Obama in their most combative encounter.
lead_paragraph: Senator John McCain used the final debate of the presidential election on Wednesday night to raise persistent and pointed questions about Senator Barack Obama’s character, judgment and policy prescriptions in a session that was by far the most spirited and combative of their encounters this fall.

headline: Oil Prices Slip Below $70 a Barrel
print_headline: OIL PRICE DROPS, AIDING ECONOMY AND CONSUMERS
abstract: Oil prices dropped below $70 a barrel for the first time in 16 months Thursday, prompting the OPEC cartel to call for an emergency meeting next week.
snippet: Oil prices dropped below $70 a barrel for the first time in 16 months Thursday, prompting the OPEC cartel to call for an emergency meeting next week.
lead_paragraph: Oil prices dropped below $70 a barrel for the first time in 14 months Thursday, prompting the OPEC cartel to call for an emergency meeting next week to establish some stability in prices that have plummeted recently after rising for months.

headline: F.B.I. Struggles to Handle Financial Fraud Cases
print_headline: F.B.I. STRUGGLING TO HANDLE WAVE OF FINANCE CASES
abstract: A focus on terrorism has limited the bureau’s ability to pursue wrongdoing related to the economic crisis.
snippet: A focus on terrorism has limited the bureau’s ability to pursue wrongdoing related to the economic crisis.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Federal Bureau of Investigation is struggling to find enough agents and resources to investigate criminal wrongdoing tied to the country’s economic crisis, according to current and former bureau officials.

headline: Concrete Tests Seen as Fraud in Parts of New York
print_headline: Concrete Tester Under Scrutiny In Fraud Case
abstract: Workers and executives at a company that tests building concrete are expected to face charges later this month.
snippet: Workers and executives at a company that tests building concrete are expected to face charges later this month.
lead_paragraph: Manhattan prosecutors are expected to seek state racketeering and fraud charges later this month against about a dozen officers and employees of a company hired to test the strength of the concrete at some of the biggest construction projects in the New York area, according to investigators and others briefed on the case.

headline: Losing Games, and Players, Hasn’t Stopped Avella
print_headline: Where Football Long Reigned, Friday Night Lights Grow Dim
abstract: The Avella High football team has been dying of malaise and lack of interest, but the Pennsylvania high school’s determination is attracting admirers.
snippet: The Avella High football team has been dying of malaise and lack of interest, but the Pennsylvania high school’s determination is attracting admirers.
lead_paragraph: AVELLA, Pa.  They have shared proud football moments at the high school here in the copper-leaved, coal-mined hills of southwestern Pennsylvania. The tales of old-timers and the championship trophies in the school hallway can attest to those days, even if teenagers in the area were not alive for any of them.

headline: As Yard Sales Boom in Hard Times, Sentiment Is First Thing to Go
print_headline: As Yard Sales Boom in Hard Times, Sentiment Is First Thing to Go
abstract: With people seeking cash in hard times, garage sales are flourishing so much that some cities are cracking down.
snippet: With people seeking cash in hard times, garage sales are flourishing so much that some cities are cracking down.
lead_paragraph: MANTECA, Calif.  As the classified ads put it, everything must go. Socks. Christmas ornaments. Microwave ovens. Three-year-old Marita Duarte’s tricycle was sold by her mother, Beatriz, to a stranger for $3 even as her daughter was riding it.

headline: Alaska Senator Is Guilty Over His Failures to Disclose Gifts
print_headline: SENATOR IS GUILTY OVER HIS FAILURES TO DISCLOSE GIFTS
abstract: Calling the verdict “unjust,” Ted Stevens, the Senate’s longest-serving Republican, asked voters to re-elect him.
snippet: Calling the verdict “unjust,” Ted Stevens, the Senate’s longest-serving Republican, asked voters to re-elect him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senator Ted Stevens, Alaska’s dominant political figure for more than four decades, was found guilty on Monday by a jury of violating federal ethics laws for failing to report tens of thousands of dollars in gifts and services he had received from friends.

headline: Consumers Feel the Next Crisis: It’s Credit Cards
print_headline: CONSUMERS FEEL THE NEXT CRISIS: IT’S CREDIT CARDS
abstract: After years of flooding Americans with offers and high limits for credit cards, lenders are cutting back sharply on both.
snippet: After years of flooding Americans with offers and high limits for credit cards, lenders are cutting back sharply on both.
lead_paragraph: First came the mortgage crisis. Now comes the credit card crisis.

headline: Obama Is Up, and Fans Fear That Jinxes It
print_headline: Obama Is Up, And Fans Fear That Jinxes It
abstract: Days from the election, liberal Democrats are not inclined to relax, given the circumstances of the last two defeats.
snippet: Days from the election, liberal Democrats are not inclined to relax, given the circumstances of the last two defeats.
lead_paragraph: In the den of his home in New Hope, Pa., a liberal Democrat sits tap-tapping at his computer.

headline: Sheepish, Proud or Set to Flip a Coin, They’re Still Undecided
print_headline: Sheepish, Proud or Set to Flip A Coin, They’re Still Undecided
abstract: Some are still wrestling with the question of how to vote. Which raises a follow-up: What is up with these people?
snippet: Some are still wrestling with the question of how to vote. Which raises a follow-up: What is up with these people?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senators Barack Obama and John McCain have stood (or sat) for 36 debates, endured thousands of interviews, and spent hundreds of millions of dollars on advertisements and the better part of two years trying to convince voters that they are worthy of the presidency, or at least a vote.

headline: Bloomberg Gets His Bill, and a Public Earful
print_headline: Bloomberg Gets His Bill, and a Public Earful
abstract: New Yorkers rendered a blunt verdict on legislation to allow Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to seek a third term.
snippet: New Yorkers rendered a blunt verdict on legislation to allow Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to seek a third term.
lead_paragraph: At times, he slouched in his chair, crossing his arms, then uncrossing them. His eyes darted around the room, sometimes settling on the clock. He fidgeted.

headline: Scientists Decode Set of Cancer Genes
print_headline: Experts Decode Cancer Patient’s Genes, Seeking Treatment Clues
abstract: Researchers have found a set of genetic mutations that may provide clues about the origins of cancer.
snippet: Researchers have found a set of genetic mutations that may provide clues about the origins of cancer.
lead_paragraph: For the first time, researchers have decoded all the genes of a person with cancer and found a set of mutations that may have caused the disease or aided its progression.

headline: Bold Impresario and City Opera Part Ways
print_headline: Bold Impresario and City Opera Part Ways Before Anybody Sings
abstract: The departure of Gerard Mortier came 21 months after New York City Opera had staked its future on his vision.
snippet: The departure of Gerard Mortier came 21 months after New York City Opera had staked its future on his vision.
lead_paragraph: In February 2007 New York City Opera staked its future on the vision of Gerard Mortier, a European impresario known for provocative productions and a penchant for shaking things up. On Friday the company and Mr. Mortier said they were parting ways.

headline: Obama Team Weighs What to Take On First
print_headline: Obama Weighing What to Take On in First Months
abstract: Advisers are trying to decide which of Barack Obama’s campaign promises need to be placed on a slower track.
snippet: Advisers are trying to decide which of Barack Obama’s campaign promises need to be placed on a slower track.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  With the economy in disarray and the nation’s treasury draining, President-elect Barack Obama and his advisers are trying to figure out which of his expansive campaign promises to push in the opening months of his tenure and which to put on a slower track.

headline: China Unveils Sweeping Plan for Economy
print_headline: China Unveils Sweeping Plan For Economy
abstract: China announced plans to spend billions on a wide array of infrastructure and social welfare projects in a bold move aimed at bolstering its economy.
snippet: China announced plans to spend billions on a wide array of infrastructure and social welfare projects in a bold move aimed at bolstering its economy.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  China announced a huge economic stimulus plan on Sunday aimed at bolstering its weakening economy, a sweeping move that could also help fight the effects of the global slowdown.

headline: U.S. Shifts Focus in Credit Bailout to the Consumer
print_headline: Bailout Effort Shifting Focus To Consumers
abstract: Henry M. Paulson Jr. is hoping to put in place a major new lending program run by the Fed and aimed at unlocking the frozen consumer credit market.
snippet: Henry M. Paulson Jr. is hoping to put in place a major new lending program run by the Fed and aimed at unlocking the frozen consumer credit market.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Treasury Department on Wednesday officially abandoned the original strategy behind its $700 billion effort to rescue the financial system, as administration officials acknowledged that banks and financial institutions were as unwilling as ever to lend to consumers.

headline: Chances Dwindle on Bailout Plan for Automakers
print_headline: CHANCES DWINDLE ON BAILOUT PLAN FOR AUTOMAKERS
abstract: Democratic leaders calling for an aid package to help auto companies conceded that they would face potentially insurmountable opposition in Congress.
snippet: Democratic leaders calling for an aid package to help auto companies conceded that they would face potentially insurmountable opposition in Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The prospects of a government rescue for the foundering American automakers dwindled Thursday as Democratic Congressional leaders conceded that they would face potentially insurmountable Republican opposition during a lame-duck session next week.

headline: Lose the BlackBerry? Yes He Can, Maybe
print_headline: Lose the BlackBerry? Yes He Can, Maybe
abstract: Security concerns and record-keeping laws mean that Barack Obama is unlikely to become the first e-mailing president.
snippet: Security concerns and record-keeping laws mean that Barack Obama is unlikely to become the first e-mailing president.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Sorry, Mr. President. Please surrender your BlackBerry.

headline: Pact, Approved in Iraq, Sets Time for U.S. Pullout
print_headline: PACT, APPROVED IN IRAQ, SETS TIME FOR U.S. PULLOUT
abstract: Iraq’s cabinet approved a security agreement that calls for a full withdrawal of American troops from the country by the end of 2011.
snippet: Iraq’s cabinet approved a security agreement that calls for a full withdrawal of American troops from the country by the end of 2011.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Iraq’s cabinet on Sunday overwhelmingly approved a proposed security agreement that calls for a full withdrawal of American forces from the country by the end of 2011. The cabinet’s decision brings a final date for the departure of American troops a significant step closer after more than five and a half years of war.

headline: Premier of Iraq Is Quietly Firing Fraud Monitors
print_headline: PREMIER OF IRAQ IS QUIETLY FIRING FRAUD MONITORS
abstract: The dismissals of Iraqi oversight officials come as estimates of corruption in the country have soared.
snippet: The dismissals of Iraqi oversight officials come as estimates of corruption in the country have soared.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  The government of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki is systematically dismissing Iraqi oversight officials, who were installed to fight corruption in Iraqi ministries by order of the American occupation administration, which had hoped to bring Western standards of accountability to the notoriously opaque and graft-ridden bureaucracy here.

headline: Al Qaeda Coldly Acknowledges Obama Victory
print_headline: Al Qaeda Offers Obama Insults and a Warning
abstract: Al Qaeda’s deputy, Ayman al-Zawahri, sought to dampen enthusiasm for Barack Obama’s election by saying that the “new face” of America only masked a “heart full of hate.”
snippet: Al Qaeda’s deputy, Ayman al-Zawahri, sought to dampen enthusiasm for Barack Obama’s election by saying that the “new face” of America only masked a “heart full of hate.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In a propaganda salvo by Al Qaeda aimed at undercutting the enthusiasm of Muslims worldwide about the American election, Osama bin Laden’s top deputy condemned President-elect Barack Obama as a “house Negro” who would continue a campaign against Islam that Al Qaeda’s leaders said was begun by President Bush.

headline: Judge Declares Five Detainees Held Illegally
print_headline: Judge Declares Five Detainees Held Illegally
abstract: A federal judge ordered the release of five Algerian men held at Guantánamo Bay for nearly seven years.
snippet: A federal judge ordered the release of five Algerian men held at Guantánamo Bay for nearly seven years.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge issued the Bush administration a sharp setback on Thursday, ruling that five Algerian men have been held unlawfully at the Guantánamo Bay detention camp for nearly seven years and ordering their release.

headline: Clinton Is Said to Accept Secretary of State Position
print_headline: Clinton Set for State Dept., Fed Official for Treasury: Ex-Rivals Uniting
abstract: Two confidants said Hillary Rodham Clinton would give up her Senate seat and accept the nomination for secretary of state after talks with the president-elect.
snippet: Two confidants said Hillary Rodham Clinton would give up her Senate seat and accept the nomination for secretary of state after talks with the president-elect.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hillary Rodham Clinton has decided to give up her Senate seat to become secretary of state in the Obama administration, making her the public face to the world for the man who dashed her own hopes for the presidency, confidants of Mrs. Clinton said Friday.

headline: Holiday Travel Is Bargain Spot for the Willing
print_headline: Holiday Travel Is Bargain Spot For the Willing
abstract: Bracing for a painful holiday season, hotels, airlines and cruise operators are offering deals to entice vacationers.
snippet: Bracing for a painful holiday season, hotels, airlines and cruise operators are offering deals to entice vacationers.
lead_paragraph: The travel industry is bracing for a painful holiday season as people scale back their discretionary spending. But that is good news for anyone who has yet to book a winter getaway, with hotels, airlines and cruise operators introducing last-minute deals to entice vacationers.

headline: U.S. Details $800 Billion Loan Plans
print_headline: U.S. Plans $800 Billion in Lending to Ease Crisis
abstract: The Fed and the Treasury signaled that they would print as much money as needed to revive the banking system.
snippet: The Fed and the Treasury signaled that they would print as much money as needed to revive the banking system.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve and the Treasury announced $800 billion in new lending programs on Tuesday, sending a message that they would print as much money as needed to revive the nation’s crippled banking system.

headline: All Eyes on Holiday Shopping Turnout in Bleak Economy
print_headline: Shopping Frenzy Takes Ugly Turn On Black Friday
abstract: The nation’s retailers are facing weak sales, reluctant customers and the prospect of the worst holiday shopping season in decades.
snippet: The nation’s retailers are facing weak sales, reluctant customers and the prospect of the worst holiday shopping season in decades.
lead_paragraph: In a sign of consumer desperation amid a bleak economy, the annual rite of retailing known as Black Friday turned chaotic and even deadly, as predawn shoppers scrambled for holiday bargains.

headline: Auto Dealerships Teeter as Big Three Decline
print_headline: Local Pillars, Auto Dealerships Teeter Amid Big Three’s Decline
abstract: Government help will probably come too late for dealers whose sales are dropping along with consumer confidence.
snippet: Government help will probably come too late for dealers whose sales are dropping along with consumer confidence.
lead_paragraph: QUINCY, Fla.  Bruce Thomas washed cars at his father’s General Motors dealership here at age 12, changed oil in high school, and sold his first Pontiac during college.

headline: Pursuing U.S. Aid, G.M. Accepts Need for Drastic Cuts
print_headline: PURSUING U.S. AID, G.M. ACCEPTS NEED FOR DRASTIC CUTS
abstract: General Motors said it needed an $18 billion package in loans and lines of credit and that it will cut jobs, factories, brands and executive pay.
snippet: General Motors said it needed an $18 billion package in loans and lines of credit and that it will cut jobs, factories, brands and executive pay.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  General Motors, increasingly desperate for a federal bailout to stave off financial collapse, told Congress on Tuesday that it was willing to drastically shrink every aspect of its operations to ensure its long-term survival.

headline: Episcopal Split as Conservatives Form New Group
print_headline: EPISCOPAL SPLIT AS CONSERVATIVES FORM NEW GROUP
abstract: Conservatives alienated over the ordination of an openly gay bishop said they would create a rival denomination.
snippet: Conservatives alienated over the ordination of an openly gay bishop said they would create a rival denomination.
lead_paragraph: WHEATON, Ill.  Conservatives alienated from the Episcopal Church announced on Wednesday that they were founding their own rival denomination, the biggest challenge yet to the authority of the Episcopal Church since it ordained an openly gay bishop five years ago.

headline: Democrats Set to Offer Loans for Carmakers
print_headline: Democrats Set To Offer Loans For Carmakers
abstract: Congress is expected to hold a vote on the short-term rescue plan for American automakers in a special session next week.
snippet: Congress is expected to hold a vote on the short-term rescue plan for American automakers in a special session next week.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Faced with staggering new unemployment figures, Democratic Congressional leaders said on Friday that they were ready to provide a short-term rescue plan for American automakers, and that they expected to hold a vote on the legislation in a special session next week.

headline: U.S. Plans a Shift to Focus Troops on Kabul Region
print_headline: U.S. PLANS A SHIFT TO FOCUS TROOPS ON KABUL REGION
abstract: The change reflects a growing concern over the Afghan capital’s vulnerability.
snippet: The change reflects a growing concern over the Afghan capital’s vulnerability.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Most of the additional American troops arriving in Afghanistan early next year will be deployed near the capital, Kabul, American military commanders here say, in a measure of how precarious the war effort has become.

headline: Detroit Bailout Is Set to Bring on More U.S. Oversight
print_headline: Detroit Bailout Is to Bring On U.S. Oversight
abstract: Congressional Democrats were drafting legislation for government control of the auto industry, including the possible creation of an oversight board.
snippet: Congressional Democrats were drafting legislation for government control of the auto industry, including the possible creation of an oversight board.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Congressional Democrats were drafting legislation Sunday for tight government control of the crippled American auto industry, including the possible creation of an oversight board made up of five cabinet secretaries and the head of the Environmental Protection Agency and led by an independent chairman or “car czar.”

headline: Calls for Governor to Quit in Scandal
print_headline: Calls for Governor to Quit In Scandal on Senate Seat
abstract: Leaders called for Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich of Illinois to step aside, as elements of the case came into focus.
snippet: Leaders called for Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich of Illinois to step aside, as elements of the case came into focus.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich of Illinois returned to work here on Wednesday amid whirlwind efforts across the state and country to remove him from office before he could make an appointment to the vacant United States Senate seat that is the root of a debilitating criminal case against him.

headline: Prominent Trader Accused of Defrauding Clients
print_headline: U.S. Arrests A Top Trader In Vast Fraud
abstract: Charges say the scheme engineered by Bernard L. Madoff caused $50 billion in losses.
snippet: Charges say the scheme engineered by Bernard L. Madoff caused $50 billion in losses.
lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, his name is legendary. With money he had made as a lifeguard on the beaches of Long Island, he built a trading powerhouse that had prospered for more than four decades. At age 70, he had become an influential spokesman for the traders who are the hidden gears of the marketplace.

headline: Official History Spotlights Iraq Rebuilding Blunders
print_headline: Official History Spotlights Iraq Rebuilding Blunders
abstract: A federal history of the U.S.-led reconstruction of Iraq depicts the effort as crippled by poor planning, waste and deception.
snippet: A federal history of the U.S.-led reconstruction of Iraq depicts the effort as crippled by poor planning, waste and deception.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  An unpublished 513-page federal history of the American-led reconstruction of Iraq depicts an effort crippled before the invasion by Pentagon planners who were hostile to the idea of rebuilding a foreign country, and then molded into a $100 billion failure by bureaucratic turf wars, spiraling violence and ignorance of the basic elements of Iraqi society and infrastructure.

headline: Caroline Kennedy Is Seeking Seat Held by Clinton
print_headline: Caroline Kennedy Is Seeking Seat Held by Clinton
abstract: Caroline Kennedy is launching a public effort to demonstrate that she has both the ability and the stomach to perform the job.
snippet: Caroline Kennedy is launching a public effort to demonstrate that she has both the ability and the stomach to perform the job.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY  Caroline Kennedy, the deeply private daughter of America’s most storied political dynasty, will seek the United States Senate seat in New York being vacated by Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Big News in Washington, but Far Fewer Cover It
print_headline: Big News in Washington, but Far Fewer Cover It
abstract: As newspapers cut costs, reporting in the capital suffers.
snippet: As newspapers cut costs, reporting in the capital suffers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A new president arrived from a new party. The balance of power shifted in Congress. Legions of fresh new faces showed up in the nation’s capital with new ideas, eager to upend the way the country does business.

headline: Car Bankruptcy Cited as Option by White House
print_headline: Car Bankruptcy Cited as Option By White House
abstract: A Bush administration official said a managed bankruptcy would be a last resort. The president is set to make a statement at 9 a.m. Eastern time.
snippet: A Bush administration official said a managed bankruptcy would be a last resort. The president is set to make a statement at 9 a.m. Eastern time.
lead_paragraph: This article is by David E. Sanger, Bill Vlasic and Micheline Maynard.

headline: Bush Aids Detroit, but Hard Choices Wait for Obama
print_headline: BUSH AIDS DETROIT, BUT HARD CHOICES WAIT FOR OBAMA
abstract: A $13.4 billion loan to General Motors and Chrysler may be followed by $4 billion more if the Obama administration finds sufficient progress.
snippet: A $13.4 billion loan to General Motors and Chrysler may be followed by $4 billion more if the Obama administration finds sufficient progress.
lead_paragraph: This article is by David E. Sanger, David M. Herszenhorn and Bill Vlasic.

headline: Bush v. Gore Set to Outlast Its Beneficiary
print_headline: Bush v. Gore Set to Outlast Its Beneficiary
abstract: The Supreme Court’s decision was never intended to set a precedent, but it is turning out to have lasting value.
snippet: The Supreme Court’s decision was never intended to set a precedent, but it is turning out to have lasting value.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON

headline: Jailed for Aiding Israel, but Pardoned by Bush
print_headline: Jailed for Aiding Israel in ’48, But Pardoned by Bush in ’08
abstract: President Bush pardoned Charlie Winters, an unlikely revolutionary in the fight for a Jewish state 60 years ago, clearing his name a quarter-century after his death.
snippet: President Bush pardoned Charlie Winters, an unlikely revolutionary in the fight for a Jewish state 60 years ago, clearing his name a quarter-century after his death.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Charlie Winters was an unlikely soldier in the fight for a Jewish state 60 years ago. An Irish Protestant from Boston, he took up the clandestine cause from his perch in Miami and helped ferry military planes to Israeli fighters, even flying a B-17 bomber across the Atlantic Ocean himself in 1948.

headline: Expansion of Clinics Shapes Bush Legacy
print_headline: For Bush, a Rise In Health Clinics Shapes a Legacy
abstract: President Bush has doubled federal financing for community health centers, enabling the creation or expansion of 1,297 clinics in underserved areas.
snippet: President Bush has doubled federal financing for community health centers, enabling the creation or expansion of 1,297 clinics in underserved areas.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE  Although the number of uninsured and the cost of coverage have ballooned under his watch, President Bush leaves office with a health care legacy in bricks and mortar: he has doubled federal financing for community health centers, enabling the creation or expansion of 1,297 clinics in medically underserved areas.

headline: After a Season of Cutting, Stores Sweeten Discounts
print_headline: Stores Sweeten The Discounts With Add-Ons
abstract: Analysts say consumers expecting even better deals after Christmas will not be disappointed, though they should expect more “bundling” from retailers.
snippet: Analysts say consumers expecting even better deals after Christmas will not be disappointed, though they should expect more “bundling” from retailers.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, reluctant consumers have forced retailers to lower their prices  and lower them again and again  before they even considered opening tight wallets and purses.

headline: As a Candidate, Kennedy Is Forceful but Elusive
print_headline: As Candidate, Kennedy Is Forceful but Elusive
abstract: Speaking to The Times, Caroline Kennedy still seemed less like a Senate candidate than an idea of one.
snippet: Speaking to The Times, Caroline Kennedy still seemed less like a Senate candidate than an idea of one.
lead_paragraph: Caroline Kennedy, the woman who would be New York’s next senator, is sure of one thing. Among all the hopefuls seeking to succeed Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, she said on Saturday, there is no better choice.

headline: No Mug? Drug Makers Cut Out Goodies for Doctors
print_headline: No Lipitor Mug? Drug Makers Cut Out Goodies for Doctors
abstract: The pharmaceutical industry has agreed to a voluntary moratorium on branded promotional items.
snippet: The pharmaceutical industry has agreed to a voluntary moratorium on branded promotional items.
lead_paragraph: To Lehman Brothers, Linens ’n Things and the blank VHS tape, add another American institution that expired in 2008: drug company trinkets.

headline: In High-Tech Game, Football Sticks to an Old Measure of Success
print_headline: In High-Tech Game, Football Sticks to an Old Measure of Success
abstract: Dozens of inventions would have improved or ended the use of chains to measure for first downs, but they endure.
snippet: Dozens of inventions would have improved or ended the use of chains to measure for first downs, but they endure.
lead_paragraph: Before there were four downs in football, before 6 points were awarded for a touchdown, even before there was an annual Rose Bowl or something called the National Football League, there were chains on the sideline.
